sentence: Great story, Cheap Jumpscares: The story was alright, it had a little bit of humour, a little bit of twist, but I wished the story showed a little bit of a long prologue before the scary parts started
It's like every filipino horror film, always start with a jumpscare or a suspense already, this makes every scare in the movie expected
The cinematic camera movements we're pretty good especially when the mother and the old century priest started dancing each other
Some of the dialogues weren't fit for the scene, but that dosen't mean the whole story is bad
The movie will be still counted for being a horror but do not expect good scares
Interesting plot
: There are pros and cons to this film
It did remind me of a Made for Television Movie, and horror elements did come across rather B Grade
Because of the latter this film may not be for everyone
Certainly elements of it could be improved upon
In terms of horror, I personally find B Grade Slashers and special effects to be rather campy and fun
So this didn't bother me at all
The reason I watched this film all the way through was 100% due to the plot to the film, I found it very interesting and well done
This isn't a perfect movie, but if you like a good story then I do recommend it
I thought it was very intriguing
I won't leave any spoilers, all I will say is that right at the end the plot caught me by surprise, which rarely happens when I watch movies
I found the Character Development, especially towards the end of the film to be executed nicely
Two particular characters were very thought provoking
Anywho, ultimately I recommend this movie for the story, and if you find horror elements that are more on the B Grade side to be fun
Lastly, I found the switching of time periods to not be confusing in this film at all
It worked smoothly in my opinion, it's actually one of the things I enjoyed the very most
It's ok: A few jump scares here and there
Movies' first half was well written
Script had humor and energy during the first half
The 2nd half, though, felt like it was originally written in English and then translated to Tagalog
Dialogue felt off sometimes and I wish the attitude of the first half carried on throughout the movie
The mystery and the way things unfold will keep you hook
But once everything is out, it all goes downhill
Ending is not something you have not seen or experience
It's been done multiple times and I wish the film could've wrapped differently
Horror fans might find this average
Good but there are buts
: "**Mallari** is a promising film within the horror genre, offering a genuinely scary and creepy experience
The atmospheric tension is palpable, and the eerie settings enhance the overall sense of dread
However, despite its strong elements, the film falls short in delivering a seamless narrative
The storytelling feels convoluted at times, which detracts from the otherwise engaging experience
The acting is commendable, with the cast delivering convincing performances that elevate the film
Additionally, the film's setting is well-executed, effectively immersing the audience in the haunting world of **Mallari**
While the presence of typical Filipino tropes might be seen as a drawback by some, I personally didn't mind them as they added a cultural authenticity to the film
Overall, **Mallari** is a solid horror film with a lot of potential
With some refinements in its storytelling, it could have been a standout in the genre
Nonetheless, it remains an enjoyable watch for horror enthusiasts and a notable entry in Filipino cinema
Had huge potential but failed miserably: Movie could've been great but as I was watching it, I got totally lost and confused as to what the movie was trying to achieve
The jump scares were so predictable and the CGI was just plain awful
What's with those CGI ghost faces
The way they CGI'd Gloria Diaz was cringey AF
Not to mention those awful manananggal wings which literally made us want to stop watching the entire film
One major ick I have was Padre Severino's weird beard
Like couldn't they have made it more natural
It looked so fake I couldn't take him seriously
They honestly should've just invested on the cast's makeup or prosthetics to make everything look convincing
I honestly could not help but compare it to cult favorite Filipino horror movies like Feng Shui and Sukob
No CGIs there but it was definitely scarier and more realistic by a mile
I still gave it four stars because, okay, it was ambitious - I'll give them that
But it was too ambitious it failed to just stick to what people came to watch the movie for - Fr
Severino Mallari's story
I think a lot of people were expecting to watch and know more of his backstory and his motivation, but sadly this was a huge opportunity missed
Will I recommend watching it
Will I watch it again
Definitely, NO
If you really are interested, save yourself the disappointment and just watch documentaries about Fr
Mallari on YouTube
The script is lacking

: The stort is about the first serial killer accounted even before jack the ripper and I really expected for it to have more eccentricities or edge in it's script alone wherein the whole concept of the movie is about the dark side of the Philippine history
The jumpscares are not that good as well, the acting of the main characters are lacking as well

However, kudos to the production team in having that courage to showcase a fresh idea in the mainstream entertainment, I have been hearing this in documentaries and podcasts for quite sometime already but not to actually watch it and be reinvented
Promising plot, brutal storytelling: I was expecting a historical narration of what transpired 200 years ago, instead I got a crappy, delusional story that's literally all over the place
I hope the writer took the time to really research this thing, instead we got something inspired by Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter
He might have come up with a great idea, then midestream decided, "heck, I don't have enough factual info I'll just swing by the fences and hope I hit gold
It's such an awful film I was embarrassed 30 mins in during movie night
Apologies to my family for dragging them to watch and waste 2+ hours of their time
FAMAS should be ashamed for giving the Best Picture award to this film
As Filipinos I'm sure we can come up with something better than this
Compelling Plot Marred by Gratuitous Jump Scares: The film "Mallari" boasts a captivating plot intricately linked to Philippine history and urban legend
The commendable acting skills of all characters significantly contribute to the film's appeal
The pacing of the movie strikes a perfect balance-neither too fast nor too slow, preventing viewers from experiencing boredom or confusion
Regrettably, the movie's downside lies in the inclusion of unnecessary jump scares, creating an abrupt disruption in the flow of the film
This drawback proves to be a significant dent in the overall quality of an otherwise promising story
Despite this setback, it's important to note that "Mallari" still stands as a commendable horror film, especially when compared to the usual offerings in the Philippine horror genre
Its compelling plot, historical ties, and the commendable performances of the cast elevate it above many counterparts, making it a worthwhile watch for enthusiasts of the genre
: The movie has it's moments
The actors did a good job with what they had, and personally, the best scenes of the movie were in the 1800s
The movie falls on a lot of tropes
It has a lot of cheap jumpscares, and I wish they'd have used more of the runtime of the film to flesh out the story, rather than use it on not-so-great jumpscares
The cinematography for this film was good, as well as the acting, but the script was just okay- this isn't to say the story is bad but the dialogue could've been written better
The story *is* ambitious, but I feel as if it wasn't fleshed out enough to be worthy of a rewatch, and the script is okay, but it did definitely wasn't good
(Personal problems or nitpicks with the movie) I can recall this one scene, near the start of the film of which I couldn't exactly point out it's purpose
Basically, a character was walking in the night, in the middle of the forest while having e-s*x
While the character has e-s*x, the murderer sneaks up from behind them and hacks them too death
The scene wasn't that sexually explicit, but the dialogue, as well as the character's hand motions made it uncomfortable to watch
If the dialogue's purpose in that scene was to be humorous, it failed- as when I watched it in a packed theater, most were silent, even when said character was hacked to death

There are more scenes to where I feel the film jumps the shark, like when a character loses their keys in an struggle with the murderer, but end up knocking them out, then going down to try and escape using their car but realizing they don't have it then going back to where the murderer is just for the key
Then a scene where the same character very clearly has the ability to kill the murderer, but does not despite the murderer having clear killing intent
I feel like this scenes like this spefically devalues and reduces the enjoyment of the film for some
We still want to watch this Mallari: Movie review of Mallari (2023) is called: "Fates Entwined: The Chilling Legacy of Fr
Juan Severino Mallari

"

When the horror movie Mallari delves into the dark and sinister tale of Fr
Juan Severino Mallari (Piolo Pascual), a once-respected Catholic priest turned malevolent serial killer haunting the village of the Philippines during the 19th century

This psychological thriller, directed by Roderick Cabrido, weaves together a spine-chilling narrative that spans three decades, connecting the fates of the Mallari family members - from John Rey in the 1940s to Jonathan in the present day
The film opens with the tranquil landscapes of the Philippines, setting the stage for the eerie events that unfold
The cinematography masterfully captures the juxtaposition of beauty and horror, enhancing the overall atmosphere of suspense
The use of dark, muted tones contributes to the unsettling ambiance, effectively drawing the audience into the depths of Fr
Mallari's twisted psyche
NOT BEST PICTURE AWARD-WORTHY: I could not understand the hype surrounding this film
I don't even think that this horror film was worthy of bagging the Best Picture trophy at the FAMAS Awards, which was the Philippines' Oscars counterpart
I really think that Piolo Pascual being the protagonist lifted the entire film to its heights
His performance was indeed one of the most excellent I've seen this year
Unfortunately, even his performance could not save the poor writing of the film
The scripts felt amateurish and second-rate
It was a wasted potential, and I wished the scenes were compressed to just one and a half hour running time

'Mallari' Misses the Mark on True Crime: "Mallari" is a fictional film based on the true story of the first serial killer who was a priest in the Philippines
This is the plot that made me want to see this movie
Turns out the movie includes elements of time travel and explores various Filipino "aswangs" and beliefs
Overall, the film isn't bad, but it focuses on the wrong ideas and characters
I would have preferred if it had delved deeper into Father Mallari's mental breakdown and what set him apart from those who choose not to commit murder
Instead, the movie emphasizes Filipino folklore, which downplays the severity of his crimes
One particular scene that I disliked is when Father Mallari tells Jonathan not to get the "sisiw", despite having killed over 50 people himself for it
The whole movie feels like an insult to the real-life victims of this priest
In summary, "Mallari" is an okay watch, but I wish it hadn't used a real-life killer and mixed it with folklore fantasy
This movie deserves more recognition

The majority catholic population 2

A haunting mix of history, faith, and horror — Mallari stands out as one of the more ambitious local thrillers in recent years
Piolo Pascual delivers a chilling and layered performance that keeps you hooked, even when the story starts blurring the line between the supernatural and psychological
The film’s atmosphere is eerie and unsettling, with stunning cinematography that makes every shadow feel alive
It’s not perfect — the pacing dips at times, and some twists feel a bit too heavy-handed — but its ambition and emotion more than make up for it
You can tell it’s a film made with vision and courage
Mallari isn’t just a horror story; it’s a tragic reflection on guilt, faith, and the darkness that lingers inside us all
The story had great potential, but the sloppy production and poor direction really let it down

The first time I watched this movie, I remember how scared I was, especially since I was watching it alone in my room at dawn
I didn’t finish it because I was too scared, and I only continued watching it in the morning
Honestly, the film was great when I first saw it
I was literally amazed by the cinematography—I mean, compared to other Filipino horror movies, the visuals here were on par with international films
The storyline was okay for me—not that outstanding, just okay
Now that I’ve rewatched it, I still find the visuals, production, and cinematography stunning
At some point, though, the film tried to do a lot of things; everything felt all over the place
Like, yeah, it’s trying everything but still gives nothing, which comes off a bit messy
I don’t know, this is just my honest opinion
For me, it could’ve been better if they focused more on the biography of Mallari rather than adding a touch of modernity to his story
Nevertheless, this film is a huge step up for the Philippine horror movie industry
Not to mention, Piolo proved his versatility by portraying various characters in this film

I’m giving Mallari a solid 4
Honestly, I didn’t expect it to be this good
The storytelling, cinematography, and atmosphere were all on point
It’s rare to see a Filipino horror film that’s this well-made and actually keeps you hooked from start to finish
The mix of history, religion, and horror worked so well together—it gave the movie a really dark and eerie vibe that sticks with you
The acting was great too, especially how the emotions and tension built up scene by scene
You can really feel the fear and mystery behind the story
What I love most is how it doesn’t rely too much on jumpscares—it’s more about the suspense, the story, and the heavy atmosphere
Plus, the sound design and visuals added so much to the overall creepiness
Overall, Mallari is one of the best local horror films I’ve seen
Disturbing, emotional, and haunting in all the right ways
I’ll rate it 4 and a half out of 5—definitely worth watching

Hooptober 12 (12/31)Country: Philippines Decade: 2020sThe story of colonial Philippines' first ever documented serial killer should be enough to sustain a fictional movie, right
The team behind Mallari thought apparently not because, somehow, all of the cliches and tropes you can possibly find in every Filipino horror movie is in this
Let's do a checklist
Aswang and other related Filipino folk horror elements 2
Haunted house  BONUS: a scene set there with children scaring each other shitless that ends with a possession 3

Jump scares galore unconvincingly shot through jump cuts, where a ghost either looks away from the camera or has a "normal" face then faces the camera with ghastly make up on accompanied by sudden jolt in the score 4

Shoehorned romance subplot as a shorthand for character motivation I can get behind these cliches if they're done well enough for me to still enjoy the movie, but I was disappointed with the lackluster script and the story structure, even early on before the reveal of the movie's supernatural bent
Mallari starts off interestingly, featuring the on-screen kill of a well-known Filipina actress in surprisingly gory detail
I honestly thought that this was going to be a straightforward slasher movie, something that is so rare in Filipino cinema, so maybe it's my fault for setting those expectations
We flash forward more than a century later with the descendant of the infamous Fr
Severino Mallari, a doctor named Jonathan De Dios, both played by Piolo Pascual

Throughout the course of the movie, Jonathan encounters through dreams, astral projection and just plain old haunting another descendant nearer his bloodline, a war documentarian named Johnrey Mallari, also portrayed by Piolo Pascual
Despite the obvious ambition in telling a multi-generational story, I'm afraid Mallari only goes downhill from there
It feels like entire scenes are excised from the movie, without care for continuity — e

, in the scene after the first contemporary murder, the cops say they went to Jonathan first but we don't see that scene ever, which doesn't add to doubts about Jonathan's identity as the new iteration of the killer
The movie suffers from clunky dialogue throughout
Character actions are written as actual speaking lines (there are a lot of expository and internal realizations spoken by the characters on their own in this movie)
Despite the cast's best efforts in their line deliveries, some come off as unintentionally hilarious (like Janella Salvador's line, "Bago ka umalis, doctor ka
Ngayon, manghuhula ka na
") or hammy (like noong hinahanap na ni JC Santos ang SISIW
with exclamation point)

Characters come and go as they please without establishing where they were in between scenes, which doesn't help if you want your audience to guess who's the one going around killing people (immediately after that first murder in the modern times, there's no doubt who it is), or if you want to establish some tension before a victim is dispatched (such was the case with Manang Mes, who is absent from the film until she was killed, only explained with a throwaway line from the cops)

There is one character who gets a little bit of background before getting killed off, but it leaves a sour taste because many of the surrounding characters say homophobic stuff (although that tracks for the world this is set in) and it also doesn't help that even that character's own lines didn't seem to be well thought of
However, it is the inclusion of the supernatural angle that made my head spin the most
Since the actual case occurred in colonial times, limited records of what exactly happened in Magalang, Pampanga exist
The real Fr
Severino Mallari's motive was indeed his mother's mysterious ailment that he thought could only be cured by killing other people
But introducing another big bad behind the big bad dampens the impact of the movie's examination of who Fr
Mallari is
This technically makes Fr
Mallari an antihero, the movie even argues he was a vigilante although I don't know if that's based on fact
Wouldn't it be more interesting to portray a character at the deep ends of his wit to comment on mental health issues that is still relevant to this day
Or using the concept of the aswang and Filipino folk beliefs as a scapegoat, which would have contrasted nicely with his status as an ordained Catholic priest
Or is the misdirect done to be more commercially pleasing

Luckily, the folk horror parts of the story tie neatly until the end, but on top of the multigeneration arc, present-day investigation, and time travel subplots, Mallari already has too much on its plate

The only things I could think of worth praising with Mallari are the production design, costumes and lighting for the parts set in 1812 and 1948 (it's obvious that the budget went there), Gloria Diaz's pitch perfect doña of the household, and the clever incorporation of Catholic iconography into the killings (St

Bartholomew is actually the patron of Magalang, and the tabak is supposed to represent the weapon used to skin him alive when he was martyred) which the movie goes out in its own way of disclaiming at the end
While I could see how this kind of movie played well during MMFF when, notably, a Shake, Rattle and Roll installment was missing from the entries, I don't necessarily recommend watching Mallari

If I were to judge it in a few words, it’s like a fanfiction of Fr
Mallari’s true crime story, which explains why it became a mix of different genres and almost far from reality
Acting-wise, Pascual was really great at portraying three different versions of himself, and I could clearly see the distinction
Special mention to JC Santos, because I never thought he could play that kind of character
In terms of narrative, I liked how it was twisted and blurry at first, but it gradually made sense as the story progressed
However, as the story escalated, the plot holes became more evident, and I was honestly confused by the last revelation, as if the first one didn’t matter at all
The cinematography was great, and the jump scares were well thought out—they didn’t rely on the usual familiar tactics
Despite these mishaps, the unrelated accounts of Fr
Mallari’s real life, and the mixed genres, they still delivered a well-crafted Filipino horror

5 out of 5
While the film had strong potential with its historical premise and intriguing concept, it ultimately falls short in delivering genuine scares
The pacing is uneven, and the horror sequences feel predictable rather than spine-chilling, leaving much of the tension flat
Despite decent performances and atmospheric visuals, the movie struggles to build sustained suspense, relying on familiar tropes instead of innovative storytelling
Mallari is watchable, but for horror fans expecting a truly frightening experience, it fails to leave a lasting impact

Mallari is a rare offering in Philippine cinema, a genre piece that dares to excavate spiritual dread through a historical lens, delivering both psychological unease and cultural reflection with surprising sophistication
Inspired by true events, the film braids fact and fiction with eerie precision, conjuring a portrait of evil that is neither gratuitous nor shallow
It does not sensationalize its horror, but rather embeds it within the folds of human frailty, trauma and unspoken guilt
What emerges is a haunting exploration of generational sin: how belief systems, when warped by grief and power, can descend into darkness
Pascual commands the screen with a quiet, brooding intensity, shifting seamlessly across timelines and psyches
His performance anchors the film's ambitious structure, which traverses multiple epochs without losing thematic coherence
The supporting cast enriches the tapestry, though it is Pascual's psychological unraveling that most compellingly draws the viewer into Mallari's descent
The cinematography is meticulously composed, leveraging lighting and period detail to amplify atmosphere rather than overshadow it
There is enough restraint in the visual language, a refusal to rely on cheap thrills, that allows the dread to simmer rather than erupt
The score, too, underscores the unease without overwhelming the narrative, enhancing moments of revelation with quiet dread
Mallari is a meditation on guilt, belief, and the persistence of evil across generations
In summoning the ghosts of the past, it forces the viewers to confront the ones we still live with

I’ve spent hours researching Juan Severino Mallari myself — not even kidding, I know more about serial killers than I do about algebra
His story
A priest who killed over 57 people just to try and heal his sick mother
That’s the kind of dark, layered horror story I LIVE for
So when I found out there was a whole-ass movie about him
I was on it
I had that trailer play a few times, even YouTube e-mailed my ass and said, "bitch, you gonna watch something else
" But I remember being hyped to watch it tonight, and boy…This movie felt like homework
Long, bloated, and just a messy watch
They seriously took creative liberties with Mallari’s story — and not in a good way
Like, that's not how his mother was treated, at all  And don’t even get me started on the VFX… I’ve seen better CGI on 2009 YouTube screamers
It gave unauthorized fan film with a budget
What stings the most is how much potential it had
They could’ve easily made a 90-minute slasher film set between 1816–1826, and it would've eaten
But instead, they threw in this confusing-ass time travel angle
Girl, be serious
And suddenly it’s supernatural
No thanks
The kills were predictable, mostly off-screen, and the rare on-screen ones were so over-the-top they looked fake
It felt like the director just watched Insidious once and said, "Yeah, I can do that
"I will say — it tried to be interesting
But this felt like someone's first time making a horror film… and it showed
If they stripped it back to its core — the madness, the religious guilt, the murders — it could’ve been powerful
Instead, it was a drag
A stylish, confused, occasionally interesting drag
My expectations were way too high
I should’ve grabbed a glass with a beverage to carry my ass through, dimmed the lights, and lowered my standards
But meanwhile, the guy who played Severino Mallari
Like fine as hell, no debate
When he showed up on screen in that priest getup, I literally whispered, "Hellooooo, fatherrrr…" The man was serving murderous thirst trap and I was eating it up
But even that face card couldn’t save this mess of a movie
While it’s not terrible, it’s definitely not good either
This had so much potential

As an avid Filipino history lover, I did a lot of research on the real-life story of Fr
Severino Mallari when I was in 10th grade for our written essay in Filipino
He was a 19th-century Catholic priest from Pampanga who was said to be the first recorded serial killer in the Philippines
He was reportedly mentally ill and murdered at least 57 people, believing that each death would help cure his ailing mother
He was eventually imprisoned and later executed by hanging
His case is considered one of the earliest recorded instances of serial killing in the country — and yet it has been largely forgotten in mainstream Philippine history until recently

So when the movie Mallari was first aired, my older sister and I immediately watched it out of both curiosity and excitement to see how director Derick Cabrido would portray such a dark and complex figure on screen

Although the movie adds a heavy layer of fiction — including themes of reincarnation, supernatural visions, and a futuristic timeline (which clearly didn't happen in real life) — it was still incredibly engaging to watch
Piolo Pascual did an excellent job portraying three different characters across the film's distinct timelines
He carried the emotional and psychological weight of the role with such depth, especially in the scenes where guilt and madness were most apparent
Almost great
The storyline is a really interesting time travelling horror mystery
It can be a bit convoluted at times, but it's also incredibly ambitious and refreshing
A tighter script would have helped tremendously
Sadly, the film relies too much on cheap jump scares with poor digital effects, especially in its first half
Worth checking out regardless of its flaws

Mallari (2023) Reviewed by: RovMallari (2023), directed by Roderick Cabrido and starring Piolo Pascual in a challenging triple role, is a gripping blend of historical horror and psychological thriller
The film explores the dark legacy of Fr
Juan Severino Mallari, a 19th-century priest turned serial killer, weaving together three generations of his family across different timelines

Pascual’s nuanced performances, which earned him a Best Actor win, and the film’s immersive production design vividly bring to life the eerie atmospheres of colonial Philippines, post-war struggles, and modern-day hauntings
The story’s exploration of inherited trauma and religious hypocrisy adds emotional depth, making Mallari more than just a conventional horror movie

The film jumps between different time periods, so it asks viewers to pay close attention, but the effort pays off with a powerful look at how evil can linger through generations and how faith can both heal and haunt

The film was well-received both critically and commercially, earning multiple accolades at the 2023 Metro Manila Film Festival, including Best Supporting Actor for JC Santos, Best Musical Score, and Third Best Picture
It also dominated the 72nd FAMAS Awards with 14 nominations and six wins, including Best Actor for Piolo Pascual and Best Picture Awards
What makes Mallari truly memorable is how it combines historical horror with deeply personal stories, resonating deeply even after watching
It’s a film that doesn’t just aim to scare, but also to explore the darker sides of human nature and family legacy in a way that feels fresh and meaningful

Mallari is a chilling horror film that explores the dark legacy of Fr
Juan Severino Mallari, a Catholic priest turned serial killer in 19th-century Philippines
The movie masterfully weaves together a suspenseful narrative that spans three decades
Roderick Cabrido's direction is commendable, bringing to life the eerie atmosphere and suspenseful plot of the film
His ability to balance horror and suspense is impressive
The cast delivers outstanding performances, bringing depth and complexity to their characters
Piolo Pascual shines as Fr
Juan Severino Mallari, capturing the character's sinister and malevolent nature
The film's cinematography is excellent, capturing the juxtaposition of beauty and horror
The use of dark, muted tones creates an unsettling ambiance, drawing the audience into the depths of Fr
Mallari's twisted psyche
The movie's pacing is well-balanced, neither too fast nor too slow, allowing viewers to fully immerse themselves in the story
The soundtrack effectively enhances the overall atmosphere of suspense and horror
The film's reliance on unnecessary jump scares disrupts the flow of the movie, creating an abrupt and jarring experience for the viewer
The CGI effects, particularly the Manananggal scene and 3D shadows, are subpar and detract from the overall quality of the film
However, the CGI old creepy face of Doña Facunda is a notable exception
Despite its drawbacks, Mallari is a commendable horror film that boasts a captivating plot, historical ties, and commendable performances
With some improvement in CGI, this film could be truly exceptional
Overall, it's a worthwhile watch for horror enthusiasts, offering a unique blend of Philippine history and urban legend

A Beautifully Shot, But Clunky and Overstuffed Horror AttemptI watched Mallari out of curiosity, intrigued by its premise and the promise of psychological horror—my favorite genre
My partner and I decided to give it a go, and while there were some strong points, the film ultimately felt like a wasted opportunity
The Good: • The cinematography, color grading, and framing choices were stunning
Certain scenes had a distinct, almost painterly quality that added to the film’s eerie atmosphere
• Piolo Pascual delivered a solid performance, effectively portraying three different characters despite criticisms that he was just “playing himself in three fonts
” • JC Santos completely stole the show in his final scenes
His performance was so gripping that I found myself thinking he might have been a better fit for Juan Severino Mallari
The Bad:1
Repetitive and Meaningless Scares • The eyeless souls were unsettling at first, but after the third time, they felt like cheap filler rather than an effective horror element
• The film never explains why the souls are trapped in the house when they were murdered elsewhere
• The scene with the children breaking into the house felt unnecessary—what was its purpose

A Confused, Overstuffed Narrative • The film tries to be everything at once—supernatural horror, historical thriller, cult mystery, and even a time-travel story—but ends up feeling like a jumbled mess
• Juan Severino Mallari was a real historical figure—the first recorded Filipino serial killer

Instead of leaning into historical horror and exploring corruption within the colonial church (which would have been a logical reason for how he got away with 57 murders), the film adds a convoluted subplot about a cult of witches raising a supernatural “sisiw” entity
• The cult’s motivations are unclear—do they want immortality
Revenge against the ruling class
It’s never explained
They just need a vessel for the sisiw… so they can take care of it
• There was already enough real-life material to craft a compelling 1800s storyline without forcing in aswang elements and cults
Instead, the film almost seems to justify Mallari’s killings, framing him as a tragic figure rather than a murderer
Inconsistent Character Writing and Awkward Shifts • Gloria Diaz’s character starts as an abusive, religiously fanatical noblewoman, hinting at her darker tendencies
But midway through the film, she’s suddenly framed as an innocent victim
This abrupt shift feels forced, as if the filmmakers changed their minds halfway through
• The CGI transformation scene (especially the “Gollum” filter on Gloria Diaz) was jarring and unconvincing
• Johnrey turning into a werewolf after taking the sisiw was the moment I officially gave up trying to rationalize anything in the film
At that point, I just thought, Okay sure, do whatever, it’s your movie
• Then they introduced time travel through astral projection, which ultimately did nothing to resolve the story’s core conflicts
Forced and Cringe-Worthy Romance • The relationship between Jonathan (Piolo Pascual) and Agnes (Janella Salvador) had zero chemistry
• Agnes, despite being introduced as an intelligent doctor, was completely one-dimensional
Her dialogue felt forced and unnatural, which wasn’t helped by Janella’s flat performance
• The romance subplot added nothing to the film
Jonathan could have uncovered his family’s dark history on his own without a love interest tagging along
• The worst moment was Agnes’ final line: “Bilog na naman ang buwan… magugutom ako mamaya
”—delivered with an unnecessary dramatic flourish, complete with removing her sunglasses to the side
It gave off girlboss slay energy in the cringiest way possible
• Also, wasn’t the sisiw’s vessel supposed to forget everything once possessed
But now she conveniently remembers everything
Sloppy writing
Final ThoughtsMallari had potential but ultimately fell apart due to weak writing, unnecessary subplots, and an overcomplicated narrative
The film would have been stronger if it had stripped away the aswang cult elements and focused purely on historical horror and psychological tension
That said, I am looking forward to Severino (the upcoming series starring Dennis Trillo)
Hopefully, they take a completely different approach— because Mallari was nothing more than a beautifully color-graded attempt at horror

ANG KABUUAN NG KANYANG MGA PAPURIMallari (Cabrido, 2024)Mallari (2024) sets the standards of what Philippine horror films must be
The quite lengthy film is an amalgamation of some of the best horror tropes presented by the author Stephen King and TV series like Supernatural and American Horror Story
Aside from these, the movie also gave an interesting mix of slasher and supernatural horror, giving an interesting storytelling
Practical effects were done perfectly, but not with its CGI, which I think, is the worst part of the entire experience
Mallari is a revolution in the country's horror films
Its highly symbolic imagery and its creative storytelling is what sums up its entire praise
I like the niche themes used here but it's poorly executed

The real life story of Father Severino Mallari has earned its place in history as the first documented serial killing in the Philippines, only to be distorted by the coersion of our supernatural preference towards acts of heinous nature

We tend to seperate and distance ourselves from the act and blame the devil, unable to accept that man is capable enough even without the devil's aid (a technique of neutralization in the Sociology of Deviance, known as denial of responsibility, wherein the deviant act is due to forces outside of the individual's control—a form of rationalization—distancing the self from the crime)

Although, it's perfectly understandable considering that the Philippine culture has deep ties with supernatural beliefs, but the modern cinematic medium should at least serve as an avenue to shed light on matters with historical basis, not to envelope it further in the occult

A very sensitive topic brought to life with a sensible and engaging story
Sure, no movie is without flaws, but I'd rather focus on the many good parts this film has to offer
The seamless connection between the three timelines was masterfully executed
As a casual moviegoer, I usually dislike movies that bombard me with questions in every scene and leave me hanging until the very end
This film, however, felt different
While it challenged me to pay attention and connect the dots, it never left me confused or frustrated
For me, this was thanks to its well-written script, brilliant acting, and superb direction

It’s proof that you can make a suspense/thriller/horror film na hindi ka nakakunot noo mo habang nanonood kasi halos wala ka nang maaninag—unlike that movie (yes, I’m looking at you, Deleter) where everyone might as well have been silhouettes in the dark - even after 2 years di pa rin ako maka-move on talaga
I absolutely enjoyed this movie, kahit na late na ako sa party
The fact that I couldn’t stop thinking about it hours after watching, and even found myself searching online to know more about it, is a testament to how great it is

I finally watched Mallari last night, and honestly, I’m so disappointed
The concept had so much potential—how could you go wrong with the story of the first parish priest turned serial killer
It’s such a compelling idea, and the plot could’ve carried itself without unnecessary additions
But instead of sticking to the suspense and thriller elements, they shoehorned in the whole “aswang” angle, which felt completely unnecessary and poorly executed
Horror like this, especially in Philippine cinema, needs to be done with care, and unfortunately, this just missed the mark
I had high hopes because of Piolo Pascual and Janella Salvador, but the film devolved into a melodrama instead of leaning into the dark, gripping thriller it was supposed to be
The script was cringe-worthy and lacked sincerity, making it hard to take the story seriously
The one saving grace
The production design
It’s clear a lot of thought went into creating the look and feel of the film, but that’s not enough to save it
Overall, Mallari was a huge letdown

*long review & slight spoilers ahead* "Mallari" (2023) had the potential to be a compelling film, but unfortunately, it fell short of expectations
The plot felt disjointed and rushed, with certain plot points (such as the astral projection and the curse) introduced abruptly and without proper development
The narrative suffered from trying to do too much (shocking considering the runtime), ultimately deviating from what could have been a more focused and impactful story
While the film attempted to address the theme of mental health in the context of religious influence, it missed the opportunity to delve deeper into this complex issue

Instead, it resorted to familiar Filipino horror tropes, relying on excessive "fear factor", predictable and unnecessary jump-scare placements, and plot twists that detracted from the overall narrative

I wish they could have possibly explored the Marxist perspective on the use of black magic as a form of resistance by the oppressed class against the ruling class, instead of just completely antagonizing/demonizing the workers of the Mallari family
One redeeming aspect of the film was its cinematography and color grading, which were visually striking and well-executed
However, the technical merits couldn't salvage the film's shortcomings in storytelling and thematic exploration
"Mallari" could have been a powerful commentary on the historical and social context of mental health in the Philippines
Instead, it became a fictionalized account that missed the opportunity to engage with more profound and meaningful themes
I can’t help but have a sour taste on my mouth given that we live in a political climate where history is being distorted, and where this film got its inspiration from is still a piece of history
Overall, "Mallari" is a film with unrealized potential
Its narrative flaws and heavy reliance on genre conventions overshadow its technical achievements and prevent it from being a truly impactful narrative

I had anticipated that the film would delve into the historical context, particularly the pre-colonial era, but it ultimately proved to be deeply disappointing in its handling of these themes
Mallari exhibits considerable potential, particularly with its intriguing exploration of the Mallari family's fate
However, the narrative raises more questions than it answers
The absence of Fr
Severino Mallari and the convoluted time-travel subplot only deepen the confusion, leaving me disoriented
The muddled timeline, coupled with a growing sense of disengagement, detracts from the film's overall impact

Didi's scene is deeply problematic, as it presents a portrayal that is highly discriminatory, particularly from the perspective of societal norms and, more pointedly, the Church's viewpointThe film's departure from its historical premise is both baffling and disappointing
What was initially anticipated as a grounded exploration of history quickly becomes difficult to comprehend, leaving me at a loss for words

"Kaylangan kong mahanap ang sisiw
" Just because you pile on a bunch of concepts doesn’t mean you’ve got a passable movie, especially when it’s sloppily executed
The story takes itself seriously, but the more serious it gets, the more it feels like a joke—mainly because it's so ungrounded
Honestly, it would have been better if they’d embraced the chaos and made it a sci-fi, romcom, or horror flick
At least then, the absurdity would have felt intentional
Let’s talk about the good stuff first: the production and art direction are gorgeous
It's a visual feast
It’s like a beautiful Instagram post that’s way too carefully curated—but then you read the caption, and it’s just gibberish
The problem is, like most Filipino horror movies, the plot spends more time explaining things than actually doing things
It’s like the filmmakers thought, "If we talk long enough, the audience won’t notice the lack of substance
" But guess what
We notice
A lot
The dialogue is shallow, the characters have zero depth, and their motivations are as clear as mud
You’ll be sitting there wondering why they’re doing what they’re doing, while the movie just hands you a 20-minute monologue to explain it all
The narrative doesn’t match the gorgeous production design, and it’s a real shame
The film is 2 hours and 9 minutes long, but trust me, it feels like 4 hours
You’ll be checking the clock, wondering if you accidentally signed up for a director’s cut of "The Lord of the Rings"

The film kind of reminds me weirdly enough of something like Psycho 3
A competent film with a bit more to say than the last, but definitely not enough to feel like a worthwhile experience
Because, there have been quite a few films similar to this over the past few decades
Films like Mike de Leon's Itim, Erik Matti's Seklusyon, Rico Maria Ilarde's Altar

These films have fascinating explorations on the difficult truths of a nation's collective past, on the definition of the family unit, and about the melding of religion on the Filipino's consciousness
On paper, Mallari has all three in spades
But, it also has the disadvantage of having a conflated story with very little to say once everything has transpired
I usually enjoy pointless genre films like those from Eddie Romero, but this one takes itself so seriously
Too seriously
I couldn't bring myself to take any of what I saw seriously, because there was nothing really thought provoking being forwarded
Yet, the film seems to act like it has something really impressive to say like M
Night Shyamalan wrote it
It shows a lot of punch with its special effects, but nothing underneath all the bells and whistles
A lot of the scenes felt particularly stagy and stilted
Seeing Piolo Pascual swallowing that cursed gastropod thing did nothing for me
And more baffling than that is this obnoxious musical score and sound design
It really takes you out of the narrative, which wasn't particularly absorbing in the first place
Personally, the very first time I had a mania for films was when I was a kid sifting through tons of horror classics
I remember falling in love with Tod Browning's Freaks, Roman Polanski's Rosemary's Baby and bawling over William Friedkin's The Exorcist
I always felt that horror gave the biggest thrill and the most exuberant high of any genre
But, I feel myself more and more disappointed the further along I see from a genre that holds a lot of sentimental value for me

Overall, Mallari feels more like a half-baked cool idea for historical fiction combining a spiritual, sci-fi element with a scary real life figure, as opposed to a compelling drama of genuine, purposive scares to bring something meaningful on what it's based on
The film is terribly forgettable

หนังสนุกดีแต่พล็อตรกมาก กวาดตั้งแต่ผีสาง ลัทธิอสุรกาย ฆาตกรต่อเนื่อง คนคลั่งศาสนา ย้อนเวลาสามรุ่น วุ่นไปถึงยุคสงครามกลางเมือง ซึ่งแอบชอบตรงที่มันดูพยายามดีโจนาธาน (Piolo Pascual) เดินทางมายังเมืองมากาลังเพื่อสืบเรื่องของบรรพบุรุษ หลวงพ่อเซเวริโน มัลลารี ที่ตามประวัติจริงถูกบันทึกเป็นฆาตกรต่อเนื่อง 57 ศพสมัยต้นศตวรรษที่ 19 จนรู้เรื่องน่าอนาถใจเบื้องหลังการกระทำของเขา ในขณะที่ยุคปัจจุบัน ก็เริ่มมีคนถูกฆ่าตายอย่างต่อเนื่องอีกครั้งเขาโกหกเรื่องคู่หมั้น แอ็กเนส (Janella Salvador) เพื่อให้ทายาทคนใช้ของตระกูล ภราดาลูคัส (JC Santos) มาช่วยสืบสาวราวเรื่อง พร้อมกับได้ค้นพบฟิล์มโบราณที่จอห์นเรย์ในปี 1948 สื่อสารถึงตัวเขา ก่อนจะพบว่าตัวเองมีความสามารถพิเศษประจำตระกูลในการย้อนเวลาขณะหลับได้หนังมีดีเป็นส่วนๆ แต่โดยรวมแล้วพล็อตมันพัลวันพัลเกเกินไปนิด ชอบการคายนกสืบทอดอสูรตามความเชื่อท้องถิ่น กับฉากอสูรแผลงฤทธิ์​ที่เหมือนกระสือถอดครึ่งตัวแต่สยายปีกเป็นสัตว์ประหลาดกันไปเลย หนังยังแอบแรงต้นเรื่องกับการออกล่าฆ่าเหยื่อที่เป็นเกย์สาวเพราะผิดบาปตามความเชื่อทางศาสนาด้วย ซึ่งฟิลิปปินส์ก็เป็นประเทศคริสต์ที่ศรัทธาค่อนข้างฝังลึกเหมือนกัน แต่เข้าใจว่าก็เป็นประเทศที่เปิดกว้างในเรื่องนี้พอสมควรนะ ;)​

Welp, I sure hope no Philippine moviegoers mistook this for the more inspiring Piolo Pascual biopic on a subversive priest during Spanish occupation
It sounds like "GomBurZa" is a more profitable Christmas release than I thought, but all other Mallaris can take comfort in this being about distancing from that name
In the 1810s, Juan Severino Mallari seems to be a perfectly decent priest in Magalang, until he discovers that a cult got a hold of his mother
He saves her soul by taking on a double-life as a serial killer whose moralistic slayings throw the town into turmoil
Over a century later, amid the Hukbalahap Rebellion, Johnrey Mallari is working on a documentary about his great-uncle when he realizes that there may be something to his delusions
2023 finally brings it all down to Jonathan Mallari de Dios, a physician who is summoned to Malang by a disturbing vision, only to be swept up in murders committed by a lookalike priest
Okay, this is at least definitely no biopic, but it may be a little too easy to mass-market

We Westerners have seen too much Jack the Ripper fanfiction for me to call that take on a historic serial killer inherently distasteful, but the ancestral slasher fantasy is indicative of the film's clumsy visions

Things are already destabilized by the lack of rhythm in how this corresponds three storylines across two centuries, that wildly convoluted structure being even harder to invest in for the respective subplots
Each storyline is also overdriven by some regressive agenda, with the 1810s probably being less grating in its Filipino religious nationalism because it's too distant from modern audiences
The 1940s is an almost comically exploitative caricature of American colonialism and xenophobic representation (Oh, we didn't have that many serial killers then
I don't think)
Before you tankies start in with "Well, actually
", the 2023 storyline is hardly woke as the lineup's most archaic slasher, with such clunky archetypes as a stupefying transphobic murder fantasy
These inane trappings and the flimsy dialogue they entail steadily overwhelm the convoluted narrative, folding its ambitions to the usual overproduced style, jump scares and exposition
Mostly, the rote supernatural slasher is distinguished by overambition
The extensive nonlinear and historical plotting practically demands your attention across 130 minutes of almost mean-spirited narrative gymnastics, ever-focused on building some grand scheme
The Philippines' "first serial killer", a paradoxical figure in his own right, sets up an interesting allegory for the nature of evil as it evolves throughout history and manifests in a lineage

However you feel about the kind of allegory that would start with "Juan Severino Mallari couldn't have been that bad if he was a priest", there is compelling character drama unraveling with the twists along this transgenerational saga

It helps that Piolo Pascual is really good at capturing the unique natures and emotional layers of his three characters, when half of the cast's acting is arguably the most horrifying part of the movie
For all of the dynamic production values and lofty storytelling around a chilling supernatural lore, I'm afraid a lot of this is typical trash horror
And as such, it matches its campy charms with genuinely freaky visuals and atmosphere, and kills or action scenes that are gruesome without being too sensationalistic
It's passably made for what it wants to be, but the first problem is that it doesn't fully know what that is

This struggles for find coherent pacing in its wildly nonlinear story, bound by awkwardly moralistic subplots and clunky writing unto classically cloying pop slasher/horror tropes, still elevated enough by the intriguing plot, themes and lead performance(s) for those rousing thrills to salvage Roderick Cabrido's "Mallari" as a soul-chilling, if a little braindead representation of evil through history
75/5 - Fair

Sometimes bonkers and sometimes unbearably cringe and unfinished, this is a film that honestly shows a bit of what Pampanga is all about
A place with a lot of haunted memories—colonialism, counterinsurgency, vigilantism, etc
—that remain repressed to preserve some fragile semblance of sanity

Mallari expands the story of the first documented serial killer in the Philippines into a fictionalised horror narrative
Both lead actors give committed performances, while the cinematography masterfully utilises the eerie charm of ancestral homes
Despite these strengths, however, the film stumbles with an overcomplicated plot that is clunky and unrewarding
More importantly, it suffers from lazy storytelling that heavily relies on time travel and recorded videos, ultimately undermining its potential

At the side of the discussion of "Gomburza" (2023) as definitely the Filipino film for that year lies "Mallari," which had a plot and premise that is so inviting and attractive
I love how this film was composed, coming from a historical drama which (unfortunately) removed its history and replaced it with folk mystery
As a horror film, it brought the classic tropes that make it as a recognizable 2020s Filipino horror film, much like the curse that the Mallari clan supposedly carried
The plot was mostly well-done, with a decent sequence (maybe except for some parts), the cast also were done well
Add to that a sprinkle of existential moralizing about personhood, decisions, the past, and the future
It has the perfect concoctions of an Eastern / Asian movie with Western elements

Although some points for improvement: I wish that there were less jumpscare moments that did not progress the plot forward, more historical elements melded into the mystery of the curse, and BETTER MUSIC, which I believe should have been filled more with orchestric slow music that conveys more drama than horror, which could also make its frightening atmosphere lasting and subtle
When the Aswangs said that they will be only heard if someone from higher hierarchy of society will speak for them, I felt it
That's reality
Poor people doesn't have a voice; only the people with money and status can speak out for their concerns because everyone will listen
However, it's doesn't justify the curse of their family and the killings
It just doesn't make sense

i anticipated its netflix release for a long time and i wish i could say that it was giving everything and more,, but given my misguided, and quite frankly, very steep expectations the only thing i can say right now is that it was extremely promising if only they focused on the structure of the story better and made more practical choices
by practical i mean mostly in terms of the special effects for the creatures and the way they aged the actors

they could have just used prosthetics and other more tangible effects and it would have looked far more believable and less jarring/out of place as opposed to the visual effects that were present throughout the entire material
as for the story
i really liked the way it enriched and utilized lower mythology and how they incorporated the various time periods in the philippines

the superstitions, mixed with factual elements, and everything in the story comprising and lending filipino-ness to the film was refreshing as opposed to the constant cliches and re-hashing of tired tropes from the west in most horror films we encounter in mainstream filipino media
the antagonist was easy to spot early on in the film, i think it was a mix of the foreshadowing/direction and the acting
perhaps they could have made less obvious choices on both the acting and script to be able to make the reveal less predictable
also there were parts in the script wherein they could have removed the dialogue
too much tell and not enough show
there were so many unnecessary monologues and it kind of removed me from urgent scenes wherein i would have appreciated just SEEING what the characters were saying out loud
it's a film
SHOW don't TELL right
the story also only really picked up its pace in the final 1/4 part of the entire running time which is a bummer
honestly it could have been trimmed down if only they removed some unnecessary monologues
if they did this the pacing of the entire film could have been better i think
overall i enjoyed it, i just felt disappointed because it could have been a cinematic masterpiece
love this film, another opportunity na gawing role ni janella ang pagiging halimaw sa ganda na haha

SPOILERS AHEAD So, my boyfriend and I just watched Mallari yesterday and it didn't fail my high expectations
It deserves the hype
As usual, I'm going to be analyzing and rating the film
I think the story is great with parallels
The transitions between different timelines work really well and it's not confusing
Great choice of the cast too
Each of them has their own singularity
It is very well-written and the storyline is just superb
There were a lot of jumpscares in this movie but there are times that it wasn't necessary
Undoubtedly, Jonrey is the best Mallari
He sacrificed himself to end the curse with him – even if it means not having to see his kid
He did everything in his capabilities to protect his loved ones
With Fr
Severino, he didn't want to do it in the first place
You could see that he was having a moral dilemma between his beliefs and his love for his mother
I couldn't blame him, I'd honestly do it too
And Jonathan
Oh Jonathan, you selfish fuck
I understand that you mean well and you wanted the love of your life to be alive but fuck you for being selfish
You only think about yourself
You never learn
You brought the curse back to life to save your fiancée, but did you really save her
Or you just turned her into a monster that hates your guts
All you guys wanted was to have a family, and now it won't be possible because of your selfishness
One more thing, I don't get the hate about the sisiw part and manananggal part
I think it plays a crucial role in the film
It doesn't deserve the hate huhu
The ending could be better but in totality, I could say that this was one of the best Filipino movies I've seen

my original motivation to watch this was purely for piolo but with every passing "plot twist", i was inching slowly into regret
severino mallari's story was simply too intriguing to resist but i predicted the messiness of compressing three generational piolos into a 2 hour film
the good aspects of this movie were accompanied by upsetting downsides (that my choosy watcher ahh decided for herself), therefore diluting its excellence into a neutral "mehh, interesting movie"
nevertheless, i had still enjoyed certain scenes (especially when i found out elisse was playing a character of my namesake
sarap pakinggan ng name ko off piolos toungue <3 kahit na medj oa yung felicity na yun hmph) which made the watch worthwhile
however, im still utterly pissed at the jumpscares that only served as reminders that this was supposed to be a horror movie
lastly, thank you closeted lucas played by jc santos

I feel the need to ask, sinong middle child kaya ang na-conceive matapos maglaba ng nanay niya noong umulan ng sama ng loob kaya nasalo lahat sa batya, tapos noong sinilang pinagdesisyunang itaas ang bandera ng mga middle child
—because this just goes to show to never underestimate the middle children
Or something along the lines
If we reach quite a bit further, the shoe will fit
I’m a strong believer that Mallari is also big on middle child propaganda
Johnrey just raised the bar, and he never got down from there

The ending, tying all the stakes to Jonathan’s choices, love, and mistakes, is probably the only end of the road that I will accept given that this film’s agenda was to take things up a notch from the current movie landscape that can be seen in our locality

Johnrey (being my favorite of the Mallari men, so let me once again shine a light on him) was there to create contrast, moral ambiguities, and drive the stakes into an extensive pitfall—and the pitfall was just that, balls-deep

Mallari, then, for all its worth and not just the ending, was an adventurous take of the Filipino supernatural lores, the historical figure that heralded the first serial killings sighted in the country, and the ambition to create a noir motion picture avant-garde among films in the industry that are still struggling to get away from the love teams and third-parties formula
Perhaps, the glaring criticism to be made is the shortcomings in execution that anchored what turned to be just potential by the end
A lot of efforts have gone into this and if we nitpick each of them, I am fairly certain that on their own, these individual efforts are granted high praises

In some aspects, however, when they are expected to work well together, they grapple with finding such a way to actually mesh in compatibility—but end up leaving one, two, or the other on a rather lackluster note, holding back what could have been a remarkable sequence

(There are choices that I disagree with, among them, sequences that translate to transphobia and hate crimes against prostitution—but to further name a few of these choices, this review would do well on that

)That is to say that, though I agree with the choice for wrapping up the primary character’s story, among (above-mentioned) other things, the progression of his character could have been subtly shown and fine tuned throughout the film
Alas, with such an extravagant narrative filled with complicated layers, the movie being too busy, the ending became abrupt
On the note of acknowledging Jonathan, his storyline couldn’t have happened without the intergenerational storyline connecting the characters that Piolo Pascual embodied
It is with such element, aided by time traveling and the use of vintage themes, that Mallari became what it is: an explored genre

In spite of my criticisms, it was still a hard work to have made a movie such as this one, and even harder still to execute interconnected storylines resulting to an impressionable film—of that, it was never a doubt
I do hope that directors and production crews alike take note of choices, as expounded in the story, and the film itself in its entirety, for future projects

I actually do not know that this film is "loosely" based on Fr
Juan Severino Mallari, who is the first documented serial killer from the Philippines
I said "loosely based" because the film even adds two unnecessary fictional characters related to Mallari
The Mallari trio is played by none other than Piolo Pascual
It is very impressive for one actor to play three roles in this film, but his "present" Mallari performance was so unconvincing throughout the film, compared to his two roles
It would've been nice if Piolo just played the actual Mallari, not this make-believe storytelling
The story is complicated and it makes me wonder what are they trying to tell other than Mallari's actions for his killings
I can't get enough about this time-travelling twist
It creates a turmoil to its story that I can't describe and say anything positive about it
If Mallari take the GomBurZa approach as a proper historical thriller, it would've been a great film
But unfortunately, the film shall take its path for being a convoluting mess with great visuals and production design

It’s been a while that i’ve seen a decent Filipino horror movie and I would say this one doesn’t disappoint
A pretty good storytelling and a very nice acting by Papa P ( i refused to call him any name otherwise, my aunts will be so proud)SFX aint that good but not bad either
Also, the song by the end are a pretty banger
The only thing is that if you’re not filipino and watched this, high chance you’ll be confused about the malignos and stuff
The folklore wasn’t explained enough and some people might not get the correlation between the supernatural beings and the chick being passed on to another person

"Mallari" was intriguing, bold and underwhelming
Seemingly a partly fictional, partly real life inspired account on the Philippines' first documented serial killer, Severino Mallari (keep in mind when
I thought there's some cool stuff in the concept/ideas department, throughout
Really liked the structure too
Well, Piolo Pascual was pretty good with his various (quite well distinguished) roles
Several other neat contributions from the cast, particularly from JC Santos
I thought the movie went a bit over its head, to be honest
Both plot and execution-wise
On a more "focused" perspective, the plot has a few glaring plotholes and some underwhelming execution (particularly where action and horror are involved, for the most part)
Several different approaches: some better, some worse (personally, I didn't enjoy some of the jumpscare technique with the editing)
Two bigger scenes
one head-on, another avoided
The plot/story, while well structured and definitely intriguing, on a closer look, should feel quite shallow in a few regards
The latter stages were reasonable, particularly again structure-wise
I didn't particularly enjoy the ending, though it should be ok-ish (if you enjoy the "reason"; I didn't and I missed some wickedness, for sure)

Overall, an ambitious and interesting movie that I felt went for more than it could manage, though it's certainly understandable that you should go for it ^_^ I felt the plot could've been stronger, particularly around the "origin/reason" and the execution could also have been better
The horror elements felt lacking, particularly in several (avoided) scenes
But I think they did pretty great in creating something quite interesting around the "main story" element

One of the best Filipino horror movies I’ve seen, Mallari is full of suspense and horror
Piolo Pascual is outstanding in his role portraying three different characters
The story begins with a man named Jonathan who returns to his hometown, uncovering a sinister ancestral curse that has plagued his family for generations
The setting has haunting visuals and an unsettling score
The flashback and present scenes tie in well with the storyline, and it’s definitely a great watch
[From trailer:]“Since I was a child, I knew something was different about my family
I hope that one day I will uncover the Mallari family secret

Mallari tackles the intersectionality of religion, faith, folklore, culture, history, and science
Spanning three different timelines, I think it was presented pretty seamlessly, though it could have been executed better
I think this performance if Piolo Pascual is a bit lukewarm
Despite their short appearances in the film, JC Santos and Janella Salvador had great performances here
For the most part, it was a bit sad that the film leaned more into the cheap jump scare horror when it could have capitalized on the opportunities brought about by religion and humanity

However, it would take a certain awareness and attention to detail to realize that there is a deeper horror embedded in the film - that love is a curse, and the lengths that a person will go through for the person they love, regardless of the consequences they face in return

Nakakatuwa dahil kaya pala natin makaisip ng ganitong konsepto na siksik sa iba’t ibang elemento

Sunod sunod ang mga plottwists sa dulo at wala itong hingahan
Piolo Pascual gave his usual good acting
You can see the distinction among the three characters he is portraying
Gloria Diaz was graceful
Geraldine Villamil was terrifying
The performance of JC Santos was impressive and applaudable, serving as one of the film’s highlights
The color grading, scoring, sound design, and cinematography altogether gave a thrilling atmosphere
The movie’s original song, composed by Quest and interpreted by juan karlos, is a powerful appropriate soundtrack
Mallari’s greatest strength still lies on its concept
The effort to be a different kind of horror film was seen and appreciated
If watching  means getting better horror stories, then count us in
Let  be the start of something new

Initially gave this four stars after leaving the theater, but after giving it some thought I’m taking it down to 3
5 Mallari (2023) boasts impeccable set design and costumes that make each time period feel robust yet still feel lived in
Pascual and Santos’ performances carry a lot of the weight of this film for me with Pascual delivering in all three roles and Santos’ grit as Lucas
Janella Salvador’s Agnes also packed a punch despite her somewhat short screen time
Apart from Pascual’s portrayal of each Mallari, the film’s choice of anchoring each era to the conflicts that affected the Filipino of its period
The feudal tensions of the 1800s and the CIA Aswang psy-op gave more body to the time periods presented
The burden each Mallari carried through time eventually made that ending make sense to me
Greed, on both systemic and intimate levels, drive the motivations of each character
Considering all of this, what made Mallari (2023) fall flat for me was its horror aspect
I am no expert on the horror genre and seeing this film made me want to read up on it haha lol but I found that the jumpscares eventually felt cheap, predictable, and unnecessary
The CGI also faltered during one scene with Doña Facunda, though it warrants a pwede na from me kasi di naman siya ganun ka-distracting

A very ambitious attempt in holding a story of three generations of the Mallari clan, adding Filipino folklore as part of its speculative writing, Mallari struggles to land smoothly
It’s a mystery/psychological thriller/folklore tale mashed into historical account of the very first Filipino serial killer
Almost all tropes from recent horror films, such as the Insidious, The Conjuring, and even The Nun series of films, appear in this film
Filipino filmography-wise, it has a touch of Nocebo and Ang Mga Kaibigan Ni Mama Susan

The plot of this film was promising, they could've focused only on the astral projection ability of the Mallari clan and build something on that alone but what happened was, they stuffed so much subplots to cut the loose ends
As the film progressed, the aswang element was added, then the caretaker element, then the curse (sisiw) inheritance, and so on
It became less interesting to me because of those subplots
I was expecting it to be a psychological horror like The Shining but the subplots kind of ruined it
Still, this film offers something new and leaves a lot of room for discussion, there is so much to unpack
Again, I really think the subplots were employed to remove the plot holes and I think they are successful in accomplishing that objective but at the expense of a better storyline

There is a point somewhere in the fuzzy third act of Mallari where a character named Agnes confronts one of the Piolos [there are four] in this movie, where she tells him: “I knew you before as a doctor
Now you’re telling me you’re a fortuneteller
” I felt her confusion so hard
Because this movie is exactly like that: it does not know what it wants to be
Because what is this
A movie about a historical serial killer
A movie about a crusading documentarian during the American colonial period
A movie about a lovelorn doctor
A movie about aswangs or manananggals
A movie about American military propaganda against the Huks
A movie about rural beliefs
A movie about social justice
A movie about the servant class eating the rich [or at least the sinful]
A movie about proto-TikTokers
[See Felicity’s final filmed confession
]A movie about
time travel
When the time travel element was introduced, that was when I finally decided to just suspend all my longing for this movie to make sense, and just surrender to the horrendous absurdity of it all

Fact was, I was so ready to do that already the first instant Mallari wanted to underline its horror elements [mostly through cheap jump scares] by announcing them with screeching music that bludgeons the viewer to pay attention and be scared
[Screeching music
A ghost
] But it doesn’t help that they mostly announce ghouls who just stand there — and do absolutely nothing of consequence
The movie does this ad infinitum that by the time we reach the 999th jump scare, you’re just
numb with boredom
Which is sad, because the story of Fr
Severino Mallari — the 18th century Filipino priest who is marked in our history as the country’s first recorded serial killer — is already so rich with narrative possibilities
Just following that story, even if the filmmakers have to embellish it to make up for the lack of concrete historical data, would have sufficed

But screenwriter Enrico Santos, perhaps fearful that he didn't have enough material to constitute a screenplay, opted to fictionalize by making this a story about a curse transcending generations, threading it all with the very hoary device of
time travel
That’s what you call a choice
A lot of the narrative elements of the film was certainly a CHOICE: killing off Mylene Dizon in the first few moments was a choice [hello, Drew Barrymore in Scream

], and then bringing in her cowering boy to the last few minutes to round off this story with an arrest was a choice; a priest spouting off “woke knowingness” and then the film proceeding to demonstrate the “kill the gays” trope was a choice; having exactly three paintings of distant ancestors hanging in an old house as shorthand for character introductions was a choice [the other ancestors don’t matter to this family

]; Elisse Joson’s acting as a bitchy Felicity was a choice; the predictability of JC Santos’ character arc from the moment he encounters Didi was a choice; the lack of serial killing was a choice; the humanizing of the serial killer was a choice; demonizing St

Bartholomew [and then making a post-script to deny this] was a choice; Piolo’s bad wig and fake beard were a choice; having characters do mouthful expository dumps as dialogue at crucial moments of high drama [to explain away gnarly narratives] was a choice — but that one with Gloria Diaz explaining the existence of a time-traveling descendant with a knife to her throat was icing on the cake; the fact that there’s only one kind of moon — a full moon always bathed in red — was a choice
I was so excited to watch this film, and purposefully made it the first MMFF entry I would watch for 2023
I left the theater wondering what could have been if the screenplay was better

“Ang isang tao ay kabuuan ng kanyang mga desisyon… minamahal… at mga pagkakamali
” (A person is made up of all of his decisions, beloveds, and mistakes
)i am usually hard to please when it comes to horror but Mallari was a pleasant surprise
the plot, particularly, piqued my interest: an origin story inspired by the very first documented Filipino serial killer, who happened to be a small town parish priest
Cabrido could easily make this a docu-style retelling but no
he took the material up a notch, made it an intergenerational story of the Mallaris, time-travelling in vignette storytelling, to unlock and reconcile each other’s past
honestly, that’s inextricably hard to land and i applaud the film just for this alone
the picturesque cinematography is just cherry on top
the vfx choices aren’t its strong suit
sometimes, i also question the relevance of its rather abundant jumpscares
that’s forgivable, at least for the most part
but you can’t dismiss how fresh this film was; how it was able to build such a unique tension with the audience made it bridge all of the mentioned shortfalls
overall, this film is a bloodcurdling picture of love—a curse in itself—as to what lengths it would take to love someone, even if we’ve become the monster ourselves
would you still call it love… or a curse spellbound

His tragic story already made it to the national television a few times

It seems like whoever developed the story for Mallari was inspired by too many TV shows and movies available on Netflix (Dark, the Fear Street series, Inception, and the Insidious franchise, just to name a few) and decided to create a film that captures the best elements from each, just packaged in a different manner
Unfortunately, what they ended up with is a film facing a serious identity crisis
It desperately wants to tell so many stories but fails to dive deeply into most of them
I left the cinema feeling disappointed because I was really looking forward to watching this
Top-notch acting from Piolo Pascual and JC Santos, though
Mallari takes place in the nineteenth century in Magalang, Pampanga
Following the crimes of Father Severino Mallari, back in the day, he used to serve the church and champion the needs of his poor countrymen
He was known as a priest who had a heart for the needy
Everything was fine until an unfortunate event took place: his mother got ill
Mallari is a film beautifully created, packed with scenes that will keep you on the edge of your seat
It was both visually and audibly beautiful
The actors were outstanding in terms of portraying their characters
JC Santos was remarkable in this flick
Piolo Pascual made another outstanding performance that will surely entertain you and make you love him more as an actor
Elise Joson was equally commendable for her short yet very effective portrayal
Janella Salvador spiced up the movie's last act with some flavor and intensity
Enrico Santos and Derick Cabrido's screenplay and direction were a match made in heaven
The cinematography, color grading, production design, and sound design were all remarkable
If you are looking for an entertaining and outstanding horror film, Mallari is definitely for you

Ang ganda na napakita nila ang tatlong magkaibang time period sa pilipinas at mas lalo ko pa ito nagustuhan kung paano nila ito tinahi at na overlap dahil sa ***tooot***

A promising concept centered on the Philippines' first serial killer who is a priest, but ultimately wasted by filling it with multiple ideas
The movie spans tropes from thriller, sci-fi, folklore, historical, romance, even family drama genres

Many interesting threads woven together, sure, but the design of this script could have been less busy so we could appreciate each one – personally, I would have liked more of a story behind the dark magic stuff so that it would be less of a twist in the final act and more of a creepy world long hidden in the shadows

Also, since the main character is a priest, a peek into the social climate of the church-centered 1800s provincial barrio would have been interesting (though I guess we already have Gomburza in the MMFF lineup to show us something like it)
This is a horror movie with high-quality visuals, so you'd think the scares should at least be good
But no, they're all cheap jumpscares carried by a loud score or sound
I will admit that being in a packed theater contributes to a better viewing experience
People were really into it, screaming at the right parts, laughing at the right parts, anticipating with bated breath the (sometimes predictable plot twists) at the right parts
Mostly, it's thanks to a solid cast led by Piolo Pascual as three different characters and his friend Lucas played by JC Santos
Technically, aside from a particularly bad CGI scene, this is a decent feat for the Philippine horror genre
If only it were more focused
