Mallari excels as a mystery/thriller, skillfully interweaving Fr
Severino Mallari's story with Filipino mythology, delving into themes of love, sacrifice, and the supernatural
For those seeking heart-pounding horror and intense scares, this might not cater to your expectations
Piolo Pascual's outstanding portrayal of three distinct characters remains a highlight, although some supporting actors struggle to match his depth, impacting the film's overall cohesiveness
Additionally, attempts at modern dialogue occasionally feel forced, aiming to resonate with contemporary audiences but often missing the mark
However, it falls short in certain technical aspects, with some special effects momentarily disrupting the immersion
Moreover, the excessive use of predictable jump scares might disappoint those seeking a more nuanced and suspenseful thriller experience
While the narrative's non-linear structure converges effectively, some scenes in the first act might feel eye-roll-worthy
Despite these initial hiccups, Mallari gains momentum over time
The clever interweaving of timelines culminates in a gripping third act, redeeming the movie's earlier flaws
Noteworthy performances, including JC Santos's compelling contribution, complement the film's exploration of mythology and folklore
Ultimately, Mallari remains a captivating watch for enthusiasts of intricate storytelling, showcasing Pascual's remarkable acting abilities

As it navigates through love, sacrifice, and the supernatural, Mallari's imperfect yet engaging portrayal leaves an indelible mark, resonating with those fascinated by the depths of human experience and the enigmatic allure of Filipino folklore
Peak Filipino cinema is back on the menu
Mallari, the 3rd film I’ve seen this MMFF 2023
Maybe I was expecting it to be good but it left me pretty disappointed
Pros: Sound design was pretty effective
I think JC Santos and Piolo Pascual’s acting was effective
Cons: Convoluted story made it hard to understand
I like non-linear storytelling, but in this case, It wasn’t executed properly
The dialogues were cringey
Aside from JC and Piolo, the supporting cast didn’t help in elevating the movie
I don’t know if its bad writing or the actors didn’t give the script justice
The insertion of humor is unnecessary and didn’t add anything to the table
I wish that they have stick to a specific storyline of the 1st Pinoy serial killer instead of adding storylines involving Filipino mythology and creatures
It guises itself to be complex but ended up dumbing the whole thing out
Visual effects could be better
the only thing redeemable about this movie is Papa P on a tank top
Ang daming gustong sabihin, pero wala namang impact
I'd appreciate it more if they just focused on one timeline and on the killer aspect
It relies on jumpscares too much
The dialogues are also awkward - trying too hard
The acting of JC Santos was so good though
The nonlinear structure, intercutting with three different timelines, finding the connection with its sometimes steady or stagnant pacing, finds its way nowhere near home
A must-be realization for Enrico Santos, the screenwriter
The killing never stops, but producing a big project with magnificent visuals with, no disrespect, a very disappointing writing shall stop
Forty-five minutes into the cinema, the film finally makes sense that the intro is trying to foreshadow — manlalakbays
No question about it
However, the use of jump scares to prolong the first act of the film is way too traditional or 2000s
Those do not contribute nor give any hint at all on why Piolo is in search of answers to their three generations of Mallari’s story
Admittedly, the first hour can be shortened to 15-25 minutes
Remove the jump scares
Just do not feed anything information through visuals; then that alone is enough for the audience to feel the genre
A bummer, still, is the used dialogues to tell a piece of information about either the timeline of the present or the story of past Piolo generations
It could have used the very evident big budget to convey information through visuals instead of throwing lines
Imagine, the film is visually pleasing and plausible, but it does not give anything or help in the progress of the plot
Such, such a waste of opportunity
The detour part of this journey is beauty — production visuals and cinematography
All-in production design
The worlds, as in three different timelines, are well put together
No one dares to refute or even question its costume or the artistic choice; the use of wardrobes and prosthetics
It speaks so much about how the audience accepts the world is shown, displayed, and given to them
Not an easy task to build a world that the audience can easily comprehend, but Mallari does it, and mind you, building THREE TIMELINES
Moreover, the sound design and music score need recognition
Although the need for a revisit in sound mixing due to its inconsistent loudness is a must, it still is a world-class quality
These perfectly and exactly convey the emotion of the characters, as well as the atmosphere of different sequences
Neither a riser nor a drone are instruments or techniques used in the film
An example is the use of bells as a score while killing the landlord in 1812
Feels bad for Piolo Pascual in a good manner
He looks exhausted by performing three characters with different distinctive personalities but conveys it justly and rightly
He may soon retire after pulling off such a performance in Mallari
No one can do that
Despite the negatives, the film counters its flaws through a good, well-thought mise-en-scene
The job of director does well in directing, putting all together by using each department’s strengths while masquerading its lows
In simple terms, the film is in the right hands, the right job, and the right driver
Writing aside due to its being subpar, all goes well
The audience just needs to learn and get used to it
Mallari successfully weaved an intricate tale of horror w/ a dash of sci-fi & folklore
It's heart however, which is a tale of love, is actually what prevented me 4m giving it a higher score
It set back its own visual myth by excessive jump scares and didacticism
Pasimplehin natin, minurder ni Enrico Santos yung sarili niyang script sa dulo with cheesy declarations na para bang bigla akong nanood ng Cathy Garcia Molina film
Yung shift gear ni Derrick Cabrido to borderline campy sa dulo eh magegets mo, ito parang tinamad o nilagnat nung sa dulo
Even though it draws inspiration from Insidious and Suspiria, it has managed to be unique and memorable
Di ba, mga ka-sisiw
The concept of having three generations of Mallari, delving on folklore and catholicism is the strength of this film
Although it was based from the true story of Fr
Severino Mallari's serial killing, it was fictionalized by creating a generation of Mallari to show how love and curse overlap over the course of time
Is curse inevitable, is anything done for love be justified, are the existential questions that can be seen with the acts of the three main characters
However, despite its good points, it has to be said that it has dumb and unnecessary parts for the sake of being called horror, like most horror films, of course
It holds so much potential
Maybe that's why it's ambitious for wanting a lot to happen
Glad that transitions are good in the middle because the beginning seemed shaky to me due to its overuse of jumpscares (that are, by the way, predictable)
Also, I see that it has to involve folklore, but does it really have to include the scene of Facunda transforming into a manananggal (just one of the many weird stuff)
The belief of killing to save more lives is enough to incorporate it
As to script, it's as if there's not much research on language use
As a Kapampangan, the sudden switch from Filipino to Kapampangan to Filipino again didn't seem natural, as if it was only used to show it explored the setting but failed nonetheless
The usage of Tagalog as to period is a bit inappropriate as well
Overall, the attempt to tell the story of the first serial killer in the Philippines in a creative way is something I can appreciate
I just wish it's more psychological
This film earns every praise
From the cinematography, direction, acting, color grading, editing, sound design, and musical score, this is unlike any Filipino horror film in recent history
While the writing and handling of multiple timelines can sometimes feel jarring, it was redeemed by its dark tone, atmosphere, twists, and a story that feels unique and very ambitious
Piolo Pascual is excellent in portraying the three lead characters
But the real surprise here is JC Santos, who gave an impressive performance as Brother Lucas
The rest of the cast gave it their all, too
The theme song for this film by juan karlos and Quest is *chef's kiss*

Padre Severino Mallari is the first document serial killer from the Philippines with 57 victims under his name
It was believed that his mother was cursed thats why Mallari resorted to unaliving to counter the black magic
What really left an impression for me from this film is the line saying, we are all Severino
Parang sinasabi sa atin na lahat tayo ay may bersyon ng sarili nating halimaw
And this clearly seen in the movie
His mother’s curse had its own form
Years later the curse takes on a different form when it moves to its next body
And along those lines we discover how intergenerational trauma is passed on
At the same time it lets us explore the deep end of what we can do when we are pushed to the brink
How much of ourselves we are willing to sacrifice in order to save a loved one
Blurring the lines between right and wrong
At napakagaling ni Piolo Pascual having to portray 3 different characters struggling along those lines

It's like it wanted to show the desperation of these people and how they fight back- but decided not to resulting into this demonized portrayal of local culture and beliefs which sucks

Pictures Philippines distributed Derick Cabrido's timeline-jumping horror flick
After all, it's riveting and perfect for mass consumption
"MALLARI", partly-historical, partly-fictional, horrifies with its convoluted yet easy-to-follow storylines of three generations amid murder, mystery, and supernatural folklore
Piolo Pascual brilliantly plays three different characters that are well-meshed in its narrative
Its thrilling score and effective jump scares (although I wish there's more slow burn approach) make a good form that we don't usually experience in most Pinoy horror films
However, there's that miss of questionable mesh on time travel and astral projection and the pitfalls of telling vs
showing narrative technique that makes the execution a bit dull
The third act redeems itself with its intense buildup and that eerie final frame serving a nod to the endless horrors of society

Nakamamahanga at nakakakilabot
Nakamamangha kasi kaya pala nating gumawa ng ganitong klase ng pelikulang makakasabay sa agos ng modernong pagkekwento
Nakakakilabot dahil ang kwentong ginamit ay may hango sa katotohanan at nakaugat sa mga bagay na kinatatakutan ng mga Pilipino
This film reinvents how Filipino horror stories were told
Marami ng pelikula ang patungkol sa mga kwento at paniniwala ng mga Pilipino pero ibang klaseng takot ang naramdaman ko rito
They utilized those elements properly and effectively
Ang pelikula ay isang malaking paglalakbay
Ginawa nila tayong manlalakbay dahil sinama nila tayo sa pag-aalam ng misteryo at sikreto sa likod ng pamilya Mallari
Sinigurado nila na mararamdaman natin ang kanilang mararanasan, makikita, at malalaman
Nakadagdag din ang magandang cinematography sa pagbuo ng intriguing na atmosphere
Nakapagbigay kilabot ang scoring para mas matakot ka pa lalo
Paniniwalaan mo ang kanilang mga practical effects na ginamit
Ilan lamang ang mga ito sa nakapagdala sa atin sa kanilang mundo
Each timeline has its distinct feel and tone, at napanindigan ito ng mga tao sa likod at harap ng kamera para masiguro na iba-iba sa pakiramdam ng manonood ang bawat panahong pinapasukan nila
Dinadala nila tayo sa iba't ibang panahon at mararamdaman mo talaga ito
Piolo Pascual definitely gave his A-game into this performance
He knew how to give that flare and nuance that will make his three portrayals different from each other
Kaya ka niyang palungkutin, pakabahin, at takutin
He is deserving to get recognition and appreciation because of his performance
He deserves that best actor award
Magagaling din ang mga ibang karakter at bagay ito sa mga artistang gumanap sa kanila
Janella Salvador had this sense of style na siya lang makakapagpamalas
Geraldine Villamil knew how to evoke terror
Elisse Joson blew my mind with her polished attitude
Gloria Diaz gave something that we never see from her until now
But out of all of the supporting characters, Jc Santos provided the most shocking performance
Dapat mong abangan ang kanyang pagganap dahil madadala ka sa kanya nang sobra
Most importantly, ang pinakanagustuhan ko sa pelikula na ito ay ang kanyang mensahe
Hindi lang siya about sa kuro-kuro ng sambayanan kundi pinakita rin dito ang mga hirap ng pamilya at ano ang makakaya mong ibigay para mapuna ang mga ito
This is a historical story of a family trying to escape from the terrors of the past that continue to creeps the present and that could greatly affect the future
With all that in mind, they knew how to tie all of it together in a jaw-dropping ending
Marami ang hindi ko inakala sa pelikulang ito
Hindi ko inakala na ganito ang kanyang kwento
Hindi ko inakala na sisigaw at matatakot ako nang sobra
At higit sa lahat, hindi ko inakala na makagagawa ang Pilipino ng ganitong klase ng pelikula

(Spoilers incoming)This almost worked
The 1800s sequences, in particular, are the film’s shining moments
It was creepy and almost compelling — the occult infiltrating Christianity/the oppressed tearing down the elite from the inside are proof that this should’ve been a period piece

In one request

A film about a crisis of faith

And when his faith was shattered
No one batted an eye

from the get-go, mallari works with an interesting premise: the first documented serial killer in the country
it takes the story a step further by introducing two other timelines, with characters that interact through lucid dreaming
the story is weaved together spectacularly, as the threads among such time periods felt smooth and weren’t forced
the concept is set up nicely, providing sufficient suspense to keep one hooked throughout the movie
i guess my most major issue with it is its framing…

While it does, at points, play like a pastiche of the most well-known genre tropes (not just horror), I am willing to overlook that nature of Mallari as what we get here, beyond the clichés, is a very meaty and layered story with pensive meditations on the bounds of a person’s love and familial loyalty

As the film was running I was thinking of how they were going to resolve the story and while I couldn’t, at the time, pinpoint how I would want the story to wrap up, I could very well list a handful of ways how I wouldn’t want the film to end and, without spoiling anything, I think they really stuck the landing with that ending
We may have different tastes and what we look for in films may be different but, Mallari, as a whole, is a film that just works, at least for me
I definitely recommend seeing this

Gorgeous production; it definitely surpassed my expectations a little bit, considering that it was a locally-made film
This is noteworthy as I don't watch them that often
However, it is also different from what I expected
I was anticipating something of a biopic, telling the story of the first-ever recorded PH serial killer
The direction that the movie took was a bit different, but it's fine, as it was still interesting
For me, the jump scares were not that effective
Considering that it is a high-budget and relatively costly production, you would expect great ones, but most of them were just cheap jump scares carried by loud sounds
The film also focused on too many genres, such as family, horror, comedy, and fantasy, to name a few
I wish those concepts were not overloaded so that we could focus more on the lore
The character of Lucas (JC Santos) was not that convincing, given that he had a huge role
It felt lackluster due to his character's development
The pacing and direction were mediocre at best
There were some highs where the theater was excited about what events might unfold next, screaming and just being hyped
However, there were also disadvantages, such as in the first act where the film was kinda hard to follow
On a positive note, the concept itself was enticing since it's about horror (my favorite genre), and the Philippine mythology was also showcased well
Piolo Pascual also looked great and proved himself to be a versatile actor
His supporting cast also did really well, providing twists and more diversity
All in all, the concept was interesting; it just was not executed to its fullest
Elements were overloaded, and it was a bit hard to follow, but the cast was great, and the production is definitely a level up from its predecessors

MALLARI How far will you go just to keep your loved ones alive
One of the best horror films I have ever watched
It is a three-timeline story that is all being connected by a single superstition
The story revolves around Fr
Severino Mallari, a true-to-life priest from Pampanga in 1812 and is the first ever documented serial killer in the Philippines
Then fictional characters Johnrey Mallari, a documentarist in 1948, and Jonathan Mallari, a doctor in the present day
The commendable cinematography paints a visually arresting landscape, showcasing a keen eye for detail in every scene
However, the film's occasional dependence on excessively loud sounds for an eerie effect raises concerns about its subtlety and may potentially overpower the audience's senses
While the narrative unfolds, numerous unnecessary jump scares seem to be sprinkled throughout
The inclusion of cheesy dialogue exchanges between Agnes and Jonathan, these moments, rather than enhancing the story, feel gratuitous and detract from the overall viewing experience
Despite these drawbacks, this film manages to reach a level of acceptability
However, there are certain parts that leave some viewers questioning the subtlety of its approach
Undoubtedly, Johnrey is my bias
He's the only one tunay, palaban, at makabayan <3[By the way, opting for a late-night cinema screening at 10:45 PM added a dimension to the viewing experience
Mallari highly delivered the fright taking this historically accurate character and building this disturbing world that bridges both "sci-fi" and Philippine folklore
It had the mass appeal of a true horror flick (including the character's dumb decisions) but still made sure that there were no loose ends
Even with these merits, it suffered a few mishaps
In the performances, Piolo did his best portraying these three separate individuals from different timelines but it did not help that JC Santos outacted him in almost all of their scenes together
The 3 characters also needed a bit more distinction but still a commendable performance nonetheless
But probably the biggest blunder is how it was overscored
The source material I believe can shine by itself without us being dictated by the score on where to get scared
And the "manananggal" too was a choice
But again, the future is bright or shall I say darker  if this is the direction our horror flicks will go to

My main takeaway from this movie is that peace as a goal, when achieved by killing socially undesirable people, is diabolical
And while we may have our own personal thoughts of unaliving bad people for the sake of a better society, it is our demons that are speaking for us
Fundamentally, the movie is a satirical expression of our human follies, including extreme desire, sanctimony, and lack of good judgement

“‘Di ba’t isang sumpa ang magmahal
”Mallari does not only showcase the story of the infamous Fr
Severino Mallari, but also delves into the lives of men from succeeding generations of his clan
The first descendant, Johnrey, a documentary filmmaker in post World War II Philippines, and the second being Jonathan De Dios, a doctor and the lead protagonist of the film
The two descendants of Fr
Severino try to discover their family’s darkest secret, which most likely has contributed to the killings and disappearances in Magalang, Pampanga
All three generations of the Mallari clan are played by Piolo Pascual, which is perceived to be difficult parts to play
However, Pascual was able to to help distinguish one generation from another and yet was able to establish the connection between all three characters
What also is depicted in the movie is the presence of important female figures in each of the Mallari men’s lives: Dona Facunda, Fr
Severino’s mother played by Ms
Gloria Diaz, Felicity, Johnrey’s wife played by Elisse Joson, and Agnes, Jonathan’s fiancee played by Janella Salvador

All three actresses gave the three women their respective well-defined characters which was able to show how each Mallari’s love for these women had urged them to take greater lengths, even if it will cost them their own morals
JC Santos does an excellent job in portraying Brother Lucas in the likeness of Brutus from Shakespeare’s Julius Caesar, as he showcases his character’s loyalty and later betrayal to Pascual’s Dr
The film may remind one of Luca Guadagnino’s Bones and All (2022) with its presence of common themes such as gore and manslaughter

It is also important to note how both Carido and Guadagnino have commonly used manslaughter as a dark metaphor for love as a motive of sacrifice and self-discovery, which the former has executed very well and evidently in Mallari (2023)

It also bears similarities with Edgar Wright’s Last Night in Soho (2021) not just with the presence of gore and manslaughter, but also with the key theme of time travel, which the two Mallari descendants have used in order to learn about the dark secret of their family for this film
The film had a well-organized flow of events, as well as a smooth transition in between time periods
It was able to give me and other viewers proper context and a good idea on how to let the story unfold and think about what could happen next
However, Jonathan’s arc was very anti-climactic towards the end yet it established his arc as an anti-hero

Another thing to love about this film is that not only did it have Gothic themes and the use of the Catholic faith, which are associated as Western literary and cultural elements, but it also incorporated the use of Filipino folk medicine and faith healing, which are indigenous Filipino cultural elements, as important parts of the film
In conclusion, Mallari (2023) was a great watch, and it definitely deserved the accolades
Not only did it bring justice to a dark love metaphor, but it also presented and promoted Filipino culture through folk medicine as key horror elements
It is a must watch for traditional Filipino horror movie buffs and those in need of a fresh face to Filipino horror films

Cabrido is adept at sensationalizing history into folk horror to a journeyman’s appeal, rendering our first recorded serial killings as that of collateral damage from Spanish and American colonial oppression
A really formally engrossing work, but potency doesn’t just stem from imagination
As for every one step this film takes forward, it takes two steps back
For Mallari, The presence of a tangible threat stems from our protagonist’s dream, and the fact that he can see
It deeply fails to create a sense of narrative urgency it needed until about halfway through, where suddenly it livens up its form and picks up a lot of heat
This is a movie that believes spectacle can be derived from the eruption of background music and a jagged, accelerated frame, which is ironic considering how listless it is a unit

MMFF Marathon Disclaimer:I went in blind to all MMFF entries this year, no idea on it but the poster, didn't even check the genres
So expect me being surprised on most things
I liked it just because I love Piolo Pascual and JC Santos (most of all JC, but let's talk about that later) but I gotta admit storytelling of this has lots of room to improve
It had a lot of jumpscares from ghosts that didn't lead to anywhere
I expected some payoff on the ghosts other than who they were, which was obvious on the getgo
When it was a slasher horror by the first act I was engaged gotta admit, but when the second act started and the time-traveling sci-fi direction went on the film kinda lost me
And when it went more fantastical by the third act by introducing witchcraft and a literal "manananggal" it lost me completely
As this is inspired from real events, I wish they just added upon the plot inspiration since that is an interesting story itself
I was just put-off on the closing title cards where they debunked their own story just to clarify the real story, because it kind of defeated the film
I feel like they accepted that the past 2 hours were fictional but then opening titles said it was inspired from true events
On the brighter side I saw a LOT of improvements here
Color grade was stellar, and lighting design
Night scenes were still visible (ehem hollywood for making night scenes literal darkness), also the VFX and make-up for the spirits were BEAUTIFUL, the "manananggal" part, not so much
Also, the production design
Set served
The amount of detail put into that was STELLAR, I was nitpicking even the wax drips of candles and they were accurate and realistic, very well-thought
Also, Piolo Pascual delivered on different nuances of different eras which made his performance very distinct
Without reintroducing who is who even with change of wardrobe, I knew who he was just by posture and speech
But what impressed me more is JC Santos, both sides of the coin in the soft-spoken to the gnarly side he delivered
The plot twist was underwhelming but his performance gave it a bit of value added

The devil (heh) may care attitude of Mallari really went to a place of the unidentifiable in Philippine cinema
It got so smart with the fusion of genres and somehow, cheated its way in something that is very interesting and cheeky
The genre mechanics became as polarized and those who found value in it, cared no less and the silliness is a great add-on to its narrative
The thematic journey of defeatist films always has a lot to say about bad decisions and the value of good as non-existent
Case in point, Christian Tafdrup's 2022 psychological horror thriller film, Speak No Evil
Said film excessively warns the audience about the eventual demise of the couple, the acceptance of one's fate just sets in
Mallari though, tries to fight back with its barbs and your usual good should always win over evil
It's funny that the whole point of the film had an underlying message that is extremely familiar in the recent and current political climate in the Philippines
The characters are represented by people, factions, and the entire nation
It's a sight for social media and fantasy for the optimist
And despite its hitches in a number of its film elements, it's relatively forgivable with the messaging that it wants to convey

I want to say it’s BEST HORROR film of the year, but my thoughts are with: the BEST FILIPINO FILM of the year
The sound design and music score is breathtaking
The writing and direction takes you to a roller coaster ride in which you can hear the audiences squealing, screaming and nervous AF
A friend of mine said, “Hindi ako mahilig sa horror, pero, gustong gusto ko ‘to
’”Piolo gave his performance of the year
A veteran actor that reminded us that our stars are so good
JC Santos and RAFFY Tejada, two theater actors, did not disappoint

But what amazes me is the jumping timelines, spearheaded by a Haunting-of-Hill-House inspired writing: and what threads them together is our dreams, to think that history repeats itself, and it only needs one protagonist to sleepwalk and realize that his worst nightmare has become the reality in his waking life
Even the set design is built from scratch
Mallari threads as our newest breed of horror, giving us something new to look forward with the Filipino indie-mainstream scene
I’d like to believe we are witnessing a renaissance for the elevation of standards of the Filipino film

There’s a bit too much to unpack with Mallari, serving too many elements that it takes away from the main narrative, and in turn removes from the scare factor aside from mostly meaningless jumpscares

While we barely even learn of the true origins of the titular character, it’s the production value that really makes the film great, from the visuals, prod design, scoring, and what is probably Piolo Pascual in his best role(s) yet
Despite its setbacks (and unnecessary homophobia/transphobia), Mallari’s production remains to be an impressive standard Filipino cinema should aspire to continue
Not much is known about priest Juan Severino Mallari, said to be the Philippines' first and only serial killer, but that was all it took to create a feature film for the Metro Manila Film Festival

"Mallari" (2023) won four awards at this year's Gabi ng Parangal — 3rd Best Picture, Best Supporting Actor for JC Santos, Best Musical Score, and Best Visual Effects — and of those four it is the latter that appears unconvincing
No doubt that win is attributed to scenes in the latter part of the film as the so-called mystery unravels, but these effects come off as cheesy like the initial jumpscares that build the film
The score by Von De Guzman can be forceful and insistent at times, but it gradually allows the film's horror structure to take charge
However Santos' win is fully well-deserved, an extreme compliment as most of his scenes are with the more seasoned Piolo Pascual and yet he manages to give his character a believable descent
That is not to be hard on Pascual though as he is given the task of juggling three different characters; his charm just happens to be too strong for this foray into horror

There is one scene though where Pascual's dramatic chops shine so bright, and it is during a silent reckoning with his actions as he dances with Gloria Diaz's Facunda, she too committed to the cause of her character
Mallari's story is undoubtedly an intriguing one to tackle, however Enrico Santos' screenplay doesn't do enough to fully utilize that premise and the plotline he decides on

Mallari is a pretty ambitious film
It's a slasher, also a sci-fi because of the time travel aspect and also a period piece
It's a fictionalized story about Severino Mallari, a parish priest in Pampanga who is the first Filipino serial killer
First, I just wanna say that the visuals were pretty amazing
As a horror fan, I'm glad to say that we are now catching up
Andaming magagandang ideas at concepts sa mga local horror films natin, di nalang tayo paulit-ulit
Praise-worthy ang cinematography and production design dito
The score is amazing, it really fits to the tone of the film
Piolo Pascual really did served, one of his best performances, I like it when he plays characters outside his comfort zone
Also JC Santos is pretty good here, he really deserves that best supporting actor award

Initially, I found myself being quite nitpicky and complaining about a couple of minor details, visuals, jump scares and effects choices
But as the movie progressed, it grew on me and eventually captured my full insatiable attention
The story pretty much revels in its intruiging mystery
It's bold and deliciously insidious
Its wicked irreverence reminds me of films like The Omen and Rosemary's Baby
Piolo taking on the three roles reminds us of how talented he is as an actor and is pretty much capable of stretching his range
The music is powerful and tickles the horror fan in me with how much it effectively marinated the movie
MALLARI has a spectacular appeal that I enjoyed, and I was also glad to hear, once more, loud screams and reactions from horror cinema audiences
In a really good way, it reminds me of those great Pinoy horror comicbooks from the good old days
MALLARI, judging from its overall package, was a solid entry, it was awesome and wickedly spectacular

MALLARI (MMFF 2023)Mallari presents an intriguing premise and stunning visuals, complemented by stellar performances from the cast
Piolo has his moments in this film
Embodying three distinct characters is no small feat
Unfortunately, he struggles to convincingly portray the nuanced differences among these characters, leaving one yearning for an acting style akin to James McAvoy in "Split
"On the contrary, JC Santos delivers an outstanding performance, effortlessly stealing the spotlight from Piolo
But despite this, the film still struggles to evoke spine-chilling moments
It relies heavily on jump scares that, unfortunately, don't significantly impact the overall storyline
Also, the narrative style of withholding key information, strategically aiming for impactful revelations towards the end, serves as one of its major pitfalls
While effective in building suspense, this approach renders characters—especially Jonathan—somewhat devoid of logical thinking, an odd characteristic given his role as a doctor
Despite these shortcomings, the film remains a worthwhile watch for those seeking a fusion of scares and suspense
SCORE: 2/5#MMFF2023 #MallariMMFF #MallariTheMovie #mallari

Set in three timelines, Mallari is inspired by the first documented serial killer, a small parish priest Fr
Severino Mallari, and how the next generations in his family are influenced by power and madness

The film gave us three Piolo Pascual who embodied three distinct characters from the three timelines and while Mallari surprises local horror fans with its twists and turns and interwoven timelines, the overabundance of cheap jumpscares and tonal mishaps made it too overwhelming and confused about its own identity
The overall production design, scoring, and Pascual's acting are the main highlights of the film
When the timelines switch, it genuinely feels like a different timeline
The nuances among the three Mallaris were all vividly portrayed by Pascual
And yes, even with the horrible-looking beard was justified
My biggest issue with the film is its confused identity
It pastes a pastiche of horror tropes that becomes too much sacrificing the narrative value of the film
Had it carefully chosen a fewer element and given a premium focus on it, the film would have been much better for me

Delving into three intertwining timelines and employing a time-traveling twist, "Mallari" presents an ambitious scope

While the writers were able to tame this beast with a narrative that manages to engage and leaving its audiences intrigued, the overreliance on jump scares and the occult fails to tie up effectively with the overall storyline
This heavy-handed (and unnecessary) approach to horror detracts from what could have been a refined, narrative-driven film instead

Jonathan Mallari de Dios (Piolo Pascual) embarks on a journey to his ancestral home in Magalang, Pampanga, in search of a hidden chamber from his childhood - a chamber purportedly holding a cure for his fiancée's (Janella Salvador) severe illness
Upon arrival, we're introduced to his ancestors: Fr
Juan Severino Mallari (Piolo Pascual), the notorious 19th-century Filipino serial killer, and Johnrey Mallari (Piolo Pascual), a chronicler of World War II in the Philippines for the Americans
As eerie occurrences unfold within the house, it becomes evident that his quest may bring more harm than good to his loved ones
In the realm of fantastical and supernatural cinema like "Mallari," stringent logic isn’t always to be expected
There's always a give and take involved as we're delving into imaginary stuff
Yet, the fundamental plot struggles to find coherence
Elements often feel forced, serving the narrative agenda without solid grounding
The biggest question for us is why is there a need to continue the legacy of murders across time
While the rationale is clear in the 1800s in Fr
Mallari's time, subsequent timelines lack this clarity and cohesion

The handling of time travel also raises eyebrow-raising issues, from small stuff such as our protagonists modern-day attire back in time without issue to seamless communication across eras to bigger issues such as the reasons how the Mallaris are able to go selectively go back in time
However, the film's glaring misstep lies in its gratuitous use of unnecessary horror and jump scares
The continuous barrage of ghostly appearances lacks purpose, serving more to frustrate than thrill
It's apparent why they put this excessive amount in "Mallari" and ironically it backfires by producing the opposite effect
Despite these drawbacks, "Mallari" maintains a level of entertainment

It's fundamentally flawed but manages to strike occasional emotional chords, buoyed by its visually captivating cinematography and commendable performances by Piolo Pascual and JC Santos in particular
Surprisingly, a degree of attachment develops with the main characters, though the film could have greatly benefited from more refinement and streamlining
"Mallari" assumes forced scares are necessary for a fulfilling experience, missing the mark on delivering a cleaner and better narrative in the process

Mallari is an ambitious film
Based on the story of the first documented Filipino serial killer, the movie could have been a gripping tale of horror and suspense
But it took a different approach and unfortunately, the execution fell a bit short in some parts
Don't get me wrong, the time-travel aspect is certainly interesting
But it left me feeling a bit disjointed and uninvested in the characters
Maybe it's just personal preference, but I prefer subtly eerie horror movies, slowly building up to the big scares that leave me on the edge of my seat and screaming my heart out
Instead, Mallari relied too heavily on jump scares and loud music that didn't quite deliver
It worked on the first few times, but it lost its novelty after a while
I left the cinema not scared shitless, but instead laughing at what just happened
But let's give credit where credit is due - the production value was stunning, sans a few VFX parts
It's easily one of the most visually impressive films from this year's MMFF batch
If only they had stuck to what they were good at and taken more risks than they could fully commit to
Overall, Mallari had so much potential that unfortunately wasn't fully realized
But it's still worth a watch for the visuals and unique take on the Philippine horror genre
Seen at SM City Dasmariñas as part of the 49th Metro Manila Film Festival

An ambitious, centuries-spanning, horror film about the first Filipino serial killer
I don't think any other local film in recent memory has attempted to take on something with this grand of a scope
The film was successful in establishing a sinister atmosphere and setting up the intrigue of how the three timelines intertwine
The non-linear storytelling challenges its viewers and helps keep the suspense alive
Back this up with excellent production and sound design and you have a very promising first half
Unfortunately, the film was not able to sustain its fascinating premise
The infusion of time travel, questionable supernatural elements, and unnecessary jump scares made for a clunky second half
The unraveling of the mystery didn't really feel satisfying and the promise of "the first Filipino serial killer" was not explored to its fullest potential
I feel like this would have been more successful as a character study instead of focusing on the supernatural side

Some elements hold it back from truly achieving greatness but Mallari is a step up from previous MMFF horror entries not named 'Seklusyon' and pushes the boundaries of how good the technical quality of pinoy films could be

In this time travelling horror mash up from director Derick Cabrido, Piolo Pascual plays not one, not two, but four different characters from three different timelines
In the first timeline, we follow the newly assigned parish priest, Fr
Severino Mallari (Pascual) and his mother, Doña Facunda (Gloria Diaz) as they both settle in the sleepy town of Magalang, Pampanga, circa 1812
Here, we learn what drove him to become the serial killer that we know today

In the second one set in 1948, we follow his descendant, filmmaker Johnrey Mallari (played again by Pascual) and his wife, Felicity (Elisse Joson), as he investigates the mysterious case of his ancestor, Severino, who has killed 57 victims
In the present time, Dr
Jonathan Mallari De Dios (Pascual) returns to his family's ancestral home in Magalang to search for a way to save his fiancé, Agnes (Janella Salvador) from dying
He believes that the cure lies at the hands of his ancestors, Doña Facunda and Severino Mallari

It's admittedly an interesting concept, as the film presents itself as inspired by the true to life crimes of Juan Severino Mallari, Phillippines' first documented serial killer during the 1800s, predating London's Jack The Ripper by more than 60 years
However, all that potential is sadly wasted in this film
Penned by Enrico Santos and helmed by Derick Cabrido, this horror film feels like a multitude of films stitched together, thanks to its many story arcs and concepts
A big chunk of the film plays out like a slasher flick, as we watch Severino Mallari dispatching a couple of victims along the way
The film also plays around with the idea of time travel and astral projection
A portion of it also feels like a creature feature, while the remaining part is your standard ghost story, as the characters are occasionally terrorized by the souls of Mallari's victims
The film is enjoyable in some parts, but as a whole, it feels convoluted
At times, it even feels confusing
The script tries to make the merging of the overarching story arcs and timelines as smooth as it can, but it can't help but feel overstuffed and too muddled
Enrico Santos' screenplay also didn't fully utilize the concept, although I appreciate the film's outlandishness
Imagine, from a serial killer, we eventually get to see ghosts, witches and aswangs in one sitting
Although I did find the film's blatant transphobia a bit icky as it didn't sit well with me
Despite that, the film is undeniably worth checking for two things: its production value and the cast
The film looks very impressive, with Pao Orendain's slick camera work brilliantly capturing Marielle Hizon's highly detailed production design
You know they really spent time and money just by looking at those highly detailed set pieces and costumes, from that town church made from scratch to the period accurate wardrobe
It's only the CGI effects that looks pretty inconsistent
The film's sound design, courtesy of Immanuel Verona and Nerrina Salim, also gives the film a more immersive experience
On top of this, the performances of the cast are worth every peso
Gloria Diaz is committed from start to finish with her character as Doña Facunda, while Janella Salvador and Elisse Joson are both effective as Agnes and Felicity
JC Santos occasionally steals the show with his compelling turn as Brother Lucas, who helps Jonathan investigate his family's dark history
But it is Piolo Pascual who keeps the entire show running as he plays four different characters in the movie
His unforgettable performance here as Juan Severino Mallari, the latter's descendants Johnrey and Jonathan, and even an evil version of St
Bartholomew is definitely for the ages
It's not exactly scary, as it spends most of its time with jump scares that, while effective, are all forgotten eventually
It's no surprise that this one's pretty divisive, as your appreciation with the film will depend on how far you can take all of its silliness

But while it does fall short of its very high aspirations, this ridiculously bonkers and incredibly ambitious time warping horror mash-up is still worth every buck, thanks to its top-notch production value and its impressive cast, led by Piolo Pascual

Since the time that the entries for MMFF 2023 were released, I was certain that “Mallari” would be the one to watch out for since it was advertised as the first Filipino documented serial killer
My expectations were high as I thought that it would be biopic storytelling, similar to GomBurZa
I appreciate the fictitious presentation of the three generations of Mallari’s
I wish that the movie mirrors how it was advertised to the public

Ika nga ni Gojo Satoru, "Love is truly the most twisted curse of all
"Watched this movie's 6:00 PM screening at SM City Cebu, and I was surprised at how long the ticketing line still is there
It's a pain to wait to buy a ticket, of course, but it just made me more excited to watch Mallari
First and foremost, I love horror movies
Literally one of my favorite genres ever
I am also one of those horror fans who have little tolerance for jump scares; it would scare me at first, but it'd eventually irritate me especially when overdone
This film could have scrapped some of those, since the way most scenes are shot already got the atmosphere to give you the creeps
The abundance of jump scares comes off like the film's underestimating the audience's perception of fear, and that aspect would have made me give this 2
5/5 stars
But the story it's trying to tell surely won me over, hence the 3 stars

Though the social commentary in the film is weaker and there are lapses in the fiction part of the narrative, it succeeds to tell how love is the main predictor for the curse that plagues the Mallari bloodline
It also successfully tells how in some cases, history is truly repeated if ignored
I see why Piolo Pascual was also others' bet for Best Actor, his acting really made the 3 main characters shine in their own ways (and his role as Fr
Pedro Pelaez in Gomburza is noteworthy too by the way, Papa P FATHERED)
Out of the 3 stories presented, my favorite definitely has to be Johnrey's
Too bad that for me, his storyline doesn't seem as fleshed out as Severino's or Jonathan's, as he is the "tragic hero" of the movie
In spite of the film's blatant flaws, it's still a movie that deserves all the hype and the awards they've received from the Gabi Ng Parangal
Do see it in cinemas before MMFF 2023 closes, it's nice to scream with other people in the cinema
"Sometimes, love is a curse and there's nothing else in the world that can break it
"Got to watched this film in an almost jampacked cinema and all I can say that it is a good balance between suspense and horror

Well, for me, it brought me back to the old horror films filled with the typical jumpscares thag you'll still get surprised but it also gives you this suspense feeling like sitting at the edge of your chair wondering what could be the next thing that will happen in the movie

The transitions between the three eras were smooth that it was a little bit confusing at first glance but I loved how it incorporates the three timelines on a single important event of the whole story and presents you each on how they are intersected at that moment
It was definitely good on how they are able to play around the plot and not spill the whole thing on one go
I loved that portion and Piolo Pascual's acting is the best I've seen and maybe this is his best movie on his entire career
From the visual, to the acting, to the pronounciations that make the timelines distinct on their own helps very well on distinguishing the three different timelines of Severino, Johnrey and Jonathan
I would also love to add some praise for JC Santos
Being a theatre kid gains you so much and we've seen it through his performance
Just two things I did not love as much
1) The Manananggal Scene (did not resonated as much or did not do anything for the plot, I guess
And a little too corny for the well produced film)2) The Ending (I am looking for more information on how things end up like that

Like from JC's character to Janella's "memory" of who she is now after what Piolo did)But despite these things, I found Mallari to be a good film and despite not being a fan of horror films, this is one of those horror films at the top my list (as it was a good horro movie and because I can still sleep st night after watching this)

Sa pagpanood ko ng 'Mallari,' hindi ko maitatangging napabilib ako sa kagandahan ng pelikula
Ang ganda ng pagkakagawa at ang twist sa kwento ay talaga namang kakaiba
Isa itong obra na nagpapatunay na may talento ang direktor na ito sa pagbuo ng kakaibang karanasan para sa manonood
Ngunit, napansin ko rin na parang may allergy ang direktor sa mga happy ending sa mga pelikula sa ngayon
Sa kabila ng ganda ng cinematography at ang kahusayan ng pagganap ni Piolo at ng buong cast, hindi maikakaila na tila iniiwasan ng pelikula ang pangwakas na may saya
Ang mga pangyayari sa pelikula ay hindi lamang maganda sa mata kundi kakaiba rin
Ang mga eksena ay nadama ko sa bawat angulo, at ang husay ng mga aktor, lalo na si Piolo at ang buong cast, ay nagbibigay-buhay sa karakter
Sa kabuuan, isang kahanga-hangang pelikula ang 'Mallari,' bagamat may konting bahid ng lungkot sa pagtatapos nito
Subalit, sa kabila nito, hindi maitatangging ang ganda at husay nito ay nagbibigay ng marka sa industriya ng pelikulang Pilipino
Btw, ang sakit sa ulo na pure tagalog ang ginamit ko sa pag-komento haha

I didn't expect much from this movie as I'd been hearing a LOT of negative reviews
I went in blind, and I happened to enjoy it
It was a horror movie that made sense (if you're open to peculiar storylines, of course)
The first half was confusing and wonky, but the latter half at least made up for it by tying up the initially disconnected events together in a way that stimulated the audience's minds
Plot twists were revealed in this way when I didn't think there was anything more to expect
The movie was intentionally NOT subtle about the true culprit's identity because there were MORE IMPORTANT twists
Some bits of dialogue, especially in the romantic scenes, were cringe-inducing and unnatural
Even Janella's and Piolo's decent acting couldn't make it bearable
The insertion of key story elements (e
, time traveling) could have been better with a less cheesy dialogue
Speaking of acting, JC Santos DESERVES the Best Supporting Actor Award
Piolo's acting was the weakest despite portraying the MAIN character; he was outshined by the supporting actors
There were multiple layers to the story that influenced the characters' complexity
Wikipedia would tell us that Fr
Juan Severino Mallari killed 57 people as a "cure" for his mother's sickness, which he deemed cursed
But the movie went all out: There was MORE to show within 2 hours
I loved the ending

Mallari is a horror-thriller film based on the Philippines' first recorded serial killer hailing from Pampanga
With this in mind, the film attempts to take us on a wild ride of discovery, boldly mixing genres that, while commendable, more often than not gets derailed into different directions
MAZES AND DAZESFirstly, it's admirable how the story attempts to give Filipino audiences something different
It marries the familiar Philippine folklore horror elements with sci-fi and mystery thriller with dashes of history, comedy, and even family drama
The story unfolds with a non-linear structure, too, which makes it interesting
The issues lay with this very idea that it wanted to do so much with so little time
The first half of the film lays all of the mystery, while the second half picks up the pace and fully turns into a horror story

Jamming too many elements somehow took away from what could have been great points in the story if only they leaned more into them and chose: did it want to be more of a historical horror or a mystery thriller slasher cult modern classic
BRIGHT AND DULL SPOTSPiolo Pascual playing multiple roles across generations would've been a great feat for an actor of his caliber
But somehow, something was missing in his portrayal that left me wanting more
His characters felt like they were the same people, save for two distinct moments in the chapel and in the hospital towards the end
Undeniable standouts were JC Santos and Gloria Diaz
They were spectacular and generous in their supporting roles and stole scenes whenever they came up beside Pascual
They were delightful to watch
OVERALLDespite its major flaws, I like how everything was wrapped up
All of the mysteries and questions set up were resolved and given their end, no loose ends (which could've easily been the case given its ambition and scope)
Mallari is an example of what happens when you allow filmmakers to be adventurous and bold in their ideas
It can lead to a bumpy and crazy, yet fun and adventurous ride
a pretty solid movie
definitely not perfect but has the potential to kickstart a new age for filipino horror movies
watching this in the cinemas was definitely a fun experience especially when the audience (mostly strangers) also insert funny commentaries here and there that you can’t help but laugh at
the people behind our backs were especially funny i couldn’t help but to acknowledge how that elevated my experience
as for the movie itself…
first, i would like to point out how much i loooooove the musical scoring
i have no complaints about that
i also liked the acting especially jc santos like woah okay best supporting actor indeed
and also liked the fact that janella salvador is here like woah everyone’s eye candy is piolo pascual but mine is janella so there’s room for everybody
that said, what i didn’t like about the movie is how they didn’t explore much about the first filipino serial killer aspect more

i went in expecting that they would explore the story of the murders itself, the aftermath, the consequences, and how the priest was discovered as the murderer but i guess that’s on me for expecting something like that, something nbc hannibal-like
honestly, i just really wished they focused more on the murders since it is a mystery/thriller aspect in itself but i guess mallari wasn’t going for that
like hello, the first documented serial killer of the philippines was a catholic priest and that in itself is intriguing as a predominantly catholic country

anyway, i did like the time traveling aspect to explore the narrative but at the same time i feel like it wasn’t utilized well enough to really wrap up the story… but props to piolo pascual for pulling off the roles well

Horror, I guess, is truly the most challenging film genre, and you feel it in the struggles of PH cinema
Often, in our horror films, the story is either unclear or unintentionally turns into comedy due to poor visual effects
In this film, I don't quite get why the fear factor feels forced
There are numerous jumpscares that seem repetitive and not very surprising
Perhaps the film could still deliver (or even be better) if the horror vibes weren't forced (especially the manananggal scene, it might have been better off excluded)
But it's still a 4-star rating from me because I did enjoy watching it
It gives off similar vibes to Seklusyon since both are horror and revolve around religion, making it inevitable to compare the two
There are few local horror films with a good screenplay, and this is one of those succeeding in that aspect
The disturbing ending was exactly what I wanted to spark discussions and curiosity about the life of Father Severino Mallari
Kudos to the filmmakers for the smooth transitions between scenes, and you genuinely feel the thrill
The score was superb (the bayle scene was chef's kiss), but there were times when the sound effects are annoying because it's too loud and hurts the ears
The editing still needs more improvement
The visual effects are far from perfect, but they're already good and a significant improvement compared to other local films, especially in the horror genre

What truly stood out here is the phenomenal acting of Piolo Pascual, with three characters portrayed, and JC Santos, who is truly deserving of his Best Supporting Actor award (they nailed it in their last scene together)
I believe Piolo Pascual is the Brad Pitt of the Philippines because he never seems to age

Its story, its riddles, its terror, and all of its aesthetically pleasing eras are cohesive
I appreciate how they told the plot without losing sight of the fact that you are still seeing a masterful horror movie

nagdala yung biceps ni doña facunda
Rather than tell a straightforward slasher/police procedural story like in most serial killer-centric films, Mallari opts for a unique approach: focusing on a historic Filipino figure
Oh and time travel as plot device
The film certainly has great ingredients
The combined acting prowess of Piolo Pascual, JC Santos, and Ms
Gloria Diaz
The Enrico Santos-penned screenplay that combines Gothic atmospheres, Catholic traditions, (almost) Lovecraftian ancient evils, love and madness, and the dance between Christianity and violence
The visuals refreshingly don't look made for TV which, in my perspective, dominates Filipino visual media today
Y'know the overly lit backgrounds
Or sickening coloring
Sadly though, Mallari is overdone but not in the fun, unique way
It falls into the usual trappings of conventional big-budget films these days (it is a Warner Brothers affair)
The jumpscares that define much of this film's genre are too one-note
A character enters a room and then there's a figure, either behind or in front, which slowly turns around, revealing black eyes, decaying skin, and mouth wide open
Dramatic score in the background to accentuate the fear
Watching it alone in a dark room can make those scenes scary, sure
But would it kill the filmmakers to create sequences that haunt, not merely surprise
Suspenseful equences that paralyze you for a minute, instead of five seconds of jumpscare
The score too, good Lord, would it kill to have silence
Let the dread creep in
Build on the minutes-long discomfort
I want to hear my own heart beating not let some loud Gregorian chant to do all the emotional carrying
final verdict: pogi ang 3 generations ng piolo

Welcome back, Philippine Horror Cinema
1) The sequencing format is superb
Despite having three different timelines, it did not lead to confusion or a "wtf is happening" moment
The timelines were executed really well
2) The amount of jumpscares, or even just the scary parts, is commendable
This is what horror movies should look like
3) Piolo Pascual's Performance is really commendable
He was able to differentiate between each character he was portraying
4) Setting / Production is great
Timelines were differentiated and can be easily identified
Areas to Improve:- Played too safe with the gore, hence it was something we don't really mind
The horror elements are enough
- 2 murders in the modern day could not justify the "serial killings", would be great if there were at least one or two more
- I, personally, did not like Janella's fate
Could've been better

The film looks good
Both in terms of production design and cinematography
The film sounds good, both in terms of sound design and scoring
The film also manages to weave together the three narratives of three generations of the Mallari clan very well
I just wish that the narrative themselves were fleshed out and developed well
It felt like the film is trying to say too much that it ended up not saying anything at all
However, I do think that the film's epilogue is easily its greatest strength
Particularly, the hospital scene
The way it was shot, the way it was scored, the performances truly hooked me in that moment

Mallari's strengths were its phenomenal acting from a star-studded cast, its great cinematography, and its pacing is okay
Mallari's weaknesses were its all over-the- place writing and personally, I think, the movie could've done better and not spoonfeed everything to the viewers and let them think for themselves
Also, it had tons of ineffective jumpscares that do not contribute anything to the plot and for some scenes, the scoring was kind of jarring and felt in-your-face
Overall, I enjoyed watching Mallari even though it's somewhat predictable
Also, we all could've saved two hours of our lives if only someone handed Jonathan a balut in the first place
Metro Manila Film Festival 2023 @ SM Megamall
Bat naging si kokey nanay ni mallari
-;        &  Noong 1800's, ang lalawigan ng Magalang, Pampanga ay saksi sa isang hanay ng mga pagpatay sa loob ng isang dekada
Isang tanyag na kura paroko na nagngangalang Juan Severino Mallari ang pinaghihinalaang pumatay sa humigit kumulang 57 katao

Sa pelikulang ito ni Direk Derick Cabrido, hindi lamang niya tinutukan ang buhay ni Father Severino bilang kauna-unahang serial killer sa Pilipinas, ito rin ay nagbibigay ng makabuluhang mensahe tungkol sa pag-ibig, bagamat isang nakakakilabot na representasyon ng pag-ibig, habang nilalakbay ang mga masalimuot na landas ng pagmamahal, kahit pa ito ay may kaakbay na panganib
Talagang hindi matatawaran ang pagganap ng isa sa pinakakilalang aktor sa bansa na si Piolo Pascual
Ibang "Papa P" ang makikita sa pelikulang ito
Iba't ibang pagkatao, iba't ibang emosyon, at iba't ibang kwento
Hindi madali ang gumanap ng tatlong persona kaya kahanga-hanga ang ipinamalas ng aktor
Isa sa gusto kong karakter na ginampanan niya ay si Father Severino Mallari
Nabigyan nya ng hustisya ang karakter na ito, makikita mo sa mga mata niya kung anong emosyon ang nais niyang ipahatid sa mga manonood
Takot, galit, at pagmamahal, walang duda, nakilala siya dahil sa kanyang angking galing
Gaya ni Piolo, ipinamalas rin ni JC Santos ang kanyang galing sa pag-arte na gumanap bilang Lucas
Isa siya sa pinakanagdala ng pelikula, kaya naman hindi nakakapagtaka na sya ang napiling bigyan ng parangal ng MMFF bilang Best Supporting Actor ngayong taon

Kakaiba ang atake na bitbit ng “Mallari” dahil hindi lamang nakasentro sa horror ang pelikula ngunit sumasaklaw din ito sa iba't ibang genre tulad ng thriller, sci-fi, folklore, kasaysayan, romance, at family drama
Nakakamangha na napagsama-sama ito sa iisang pelikula
Mahusay nitong inilarawan ang kontradiksyon ng pag-ibig bilang isang biyaya at sumpa
Katulad ng sinabi sa pelikula “Ang isang tao ay kabuuan ng kaniyang mga desisyon, minamahal, at mga pagkakamali," gaano nga ba kalalim ang kaya nating isugal para sa pag-ibig

Presenting the Piolo Pascual Multiverse of Madness
Mallari commits to taking advantage of the Filipino lore to create a piece that can be exciting despite going all over the place for perhaps half of the time
The film wanted to be many different things all at once and truly attempted to connect the dots but not without shortcomings
There are justifiable parts, then there are “what the hell is going on” ones
Regardless of the mishaps, such as the lack of cinematic fluidity and overpowering score, Mallari is an entertaining experience - thanks to Piolo Pascual’s constant reinvention as an actor

I personally appreciated the homage to our long history of integrating elements of religion, mythology, and superstitions that has been effective as early as the Spanish Colonial Period in the Philippines

The Philippine Horror Movie scene has had a very interesting existence, to say the least

Our culture is ripe with legends and fables about supernatural beings committing atrocities, and many variations of these tales have made their way to the silver screen - whether that be a refrigerator eating an unwelcome houseguest, or centuries-old entities luring influencers to a “collab” to harvest their fresh flesh and blood

Sometimes, we get tales of a feminine spectre haunting a commonly-used thoroughfare in Quezon City, and sometimes we’ll get a tale about the horrors that have befallen families simply because they’ve set wedding dates so close to each other
One horror trope, which has not been explored much in Filipino cinema, is that of the serial killer slasher film
One film dares to go deeper into that sub-genre, an attempt that has elicited much anticipation and hype
The question is, does the film live up to said hype
Full review here: www

The concept of exploring the Philippines' only recorded serial killer was an excellent idea, but the execution was blown out of proportion
There was so much happening and too many themes were being introduced
While the intention was there, it was just too ambitious for its own good
Also, the jump-scare-galore type of horror made it less and less "scary" nearing the end
On the other hand, the inclusion of Philippine lore, the eerie sound design & score, and excellent acting (especially JC Santos) were the film's redeeming factors
Overall, it wasn't a bad film through and through, but it could have been better

I mean—
The concept of time travel in storytelling is a nice approach

It was well presented how the 3 different generations of Mallari were portrayed, but it also showcased that—even now and then, there’s a curse that has been happening in our country (in the context of societal injustices)
“Ang isang tao ay kabuuan ng kanyang mga desisyon… minamahal… at mga pagkakamali
”The Love lies at the core of all three varieties of Mallari
Two are driven by love for their spouses, and one is out of love for the mother
However, Jonathan and Juan Severino both have the trait of sacrificing others in order to save their loved ones
Johnray, however, gives his life to save everyone, even his loved ones
It all leads me to the question: to what extents are we willing to go for the sake of love
For the production, when it comes to horror, it’s either you go big or go home

This means that to be able to justify the concept of a horror film, you will need to exert a lot of effort in executing it, from cinematography, lights, sound design, production design, and wardrobe & prosthetics
I applaud the sound design that carried the whole jump scare, the lights that signified each scenery, the PD, wardrobe, & hmu, who emphasized the time frame, symbolism, and their story as a character
Though there are some unnecessary parts and certain areas that could use of improvement, but overall, I applaud how well they have shown the history, culture, and Filipino myths in this film

The messages they unfold about societal issues, needs to be recognized more; hence, they tackle serious issues such as the injustice killing which represents the EJK, and how the lgbtq community is still considered as part of the “salot ng lipunan”, and many more, that are still happening today

Making the Philippine’s first recorded serial killer a side character rather than the main lead was a miss
There’s so much lore and history around the character just for it to be overshadowed by present time’s Mallari and his spiral
If the movie was solely about the priest, it would’ve been a fucking hit, but I admire the unique take on astral projection and time traveling
While I applaud Piolo Pascual’s talent in portraying three different characters, I can’t help but think if there would’ve been a better way to introduce these characters and their stories

The constant flashbacks and sudden time jumps were bordering on overkill, I personally would’ve enjoyed if the movie was sectioned into three parts instead to have a consistent story line because trying to decipher each time period’s plot made the movie feel longer than it actually was
Reading the wikipedia plot was more entertaining
Also, what the hell is this movie’s lightning problem
A majority of the jump scares are either the killer or ghosts in the background but I wouldn’t know because I couldn’t see shit
Speaking of jump scares, Philippine cinema needs to find new ways of scaring its viewers rather than the typical ~scary image~ with loud music
I admit, some of it worked, but the tension in teasing a potential jump scare is more memorable than a lousy 5 second scare imo
Or maybe I’m just used to the American horror movie industry and the likes of Blumhouse or A24

To cut it sweet, the parts I liked: the hospital scene at the end being shown in the beginning, each Mallari’s origins in how all three ended up being in one room at the same time shown throughout the movie, Janella Salvador, the manananggal reveal, generational Alarcon vs Mallari, Piolo Pascual’s acting, and the overall filmography of it all
Would I watch it again
Mhm, probably not
Did I still enjoy seeing Piolo Pascaul and Janella Salvador on the big screen
Hell fucking yes

Plot: No loopholes, everything was answered and nasatisfy ako until the end kasi it lets me think on what happens next pero at the same time I don’t need na kasi every part of the story is enough to keep you satisfied and kasi you already know what happens to the Mallari Family
The storyline will flow with you and will answer all of your questions
Jump-scares: Medyo OA lang some scenes ng ibang ghosts hindi ko talaga bet haha
Para lang siyang in-add out of nowhere sa script to make it “scarier” since plain nga lang talaga ang flow pag Serial Killers ang story
They added that “oomph” badly pero gets naman na pinoy medyo need ng OA sa life char
When you rewind the clips siguro di talaga nakakatakot yung faces, nakakagulat lang pero “eh” ang makeup, for me, + may OA din na SFX during jumpscares na di ko nabet-an
It’s too much
Acting: hands down to Piolo Pascual for portraying 3 DIFFERENT CHARACTERS flawlessly
Ang galing at walang bahid/mix ng other characters na Mallari
Siguro given na din na they’re from different timelines pero kitang kita mo yung difference ng character and harmony nila together as “Mallaris”
Special mention to JC Santos
Napakaganda ng execution niya with his character
+ the women in the film Janella and Elisse very strong characters indeed
Cinematography: Seamless and Experimental Since the story has 3 different timelines, it jumps from one timeline to another and super clean ng transitions
Experimental in a way na they’ve incorporated transitions to jump from one dialogue to another and from one Mallari to the next Mallari in another timeline
For the color grading, *chef’s kiss* it speaks for itself and bawat history ng family nila seamless ang colors
All in all, ganda ng execution
Camera Work:  super love it di ko na explain watch niyo nalang very visible yung ganda ng camera work nila
Production Design: THE BEST
Bawat details sa set ng timelines kuhang kuha
It feels so alive na parang nangyari talaga siya in real life
Slasher Factor: At the end of the day, it’s a story about a Serial Killer, medyo nakulangan lang ako sa Serial Killer factor niya
With the slashing scenes, nabitin ako
Kulang sa patayan
Medyo heavily kasi nag focus yung story sa Filipino Theme na may added witchcraft, superstitions, folklore
Which is gets ko kasi it’s a Filipino Serial Killer it’s bound to be incorporated with Filipino themes
With the added themes, it’s too chaotic, in somewhat a good way
Though sana dinagdagan pa nila yung slashing and killings kasi bitin
For the gore, pwede na ilaban

AdditionalSince this is Fiction, some scenes are familiar sa other Horror/Thriller Films that I’ve watched kaya parang magegets mo na din yung scene or mahahalata mo na influenced siya with a certain film
Films like Mallari: Sinister, Insidious, Lights Out Sucker for history and true crime

MALLARI, MMFF2023: Based on Filipino Catholic priest Juan Severino Mallari (1785–1840), the first documented serial killer from the Philippines; Director Roderick Cabrido and writer Enrico Santos deliver a story that takes the premise of Mallari's serial killing and uses it as backstory to advance the horror elements of the film's three-timeline, three-Piolo Pascual act

Personally, I might be in the minority who thinks that, with reports of Mallari showing signs of mental instability around the same time of his killing spree, the film would have worked better as a psychological thriller, sans the folk horror aspect
The filmmakers seemingly took advantage of the paucity of verifiable records about the man's life — so much that the liberties they took just screams 'WOW'
Mallari, in its sheer unapologetic glory, is a very interesting mess
As an alchemy of historical thriller and folk horror, at times it becomes too tiring, that audiences can be forgiven for expecting scares before they even appear onscreen
This marriage ultimately combusts in the end, leaving only one of the two as the last genre standing

And for that, flaws and all, I feel Mallari deserves a closer look for its guts to prioritize jump scares to frighten its audiences shitless; even if by doing so, it compromises history — and the last ounces of accuracy remaining — by putting it on the back burner

(Note: This review contains spoilers
)This is certainly one of the most bizarre films I’ve ever seen
I entered the theater expecting a retelling of Juan Severino Mallari’s story in the form of a slasher film, but ended up witnessing something completely different
My expectations were completely subverted
The film took so much creative license and put some fantasy and supernatural twists on Juan Severino Mallari’s story, which is really inventive
But while I do appreciate this creative effort, I was not quite satisfied with its outcome
As much as I want to give lots of praises to the film, I believe it has some flaws, which, unfortunately, brought down its quality
Frankly, the film was too ambitious
It tried too hard to present a complex and mind-boggling concept but ended up executing it poorly
Hence, when I left the theater, I felt that something was missing
The film didn’t turn out to be as impressive and groundbreaking as I expected it to be
Perhaps, they should have just focused on the time travel aspect, because that was done brilliantly
Fusing it with Juan Severino Mallari’s story and excessive supernatural elements ruined what could have been an amazing time-travel historical film
The foundation was already there
It would’ve created something truly impressive and groundbreaking, until… the poor execution of the story’s very ambitious plot
Also, the dialogues were clunky
Many of the conversations between characters who are supposedly close to one another felt forced and awkward
An example is when Jonathan suddenly shouted at Lucas after the latter butted in on his conversation with Agnes
His shouting came out of nowhere, and it felt so forced
Sure, he was angry at Lucas, but I didn’t feel its emotional weight due to how forced it was
(I’m aware of the reason for Jonathan’s anger, it’s the clunky dialogue that’s the problem
) There are more instances like this throughout the film, and it really bothered me
The timing of the dialogues, as well as the choice of words, were really off
But despite my gripes with the film, I’m gonna give it three stars because it has some redeeming qualities
Among these are Piolo Pascual and JC Santos’ impeccable performances
I was absolutely impressed with how Piolo was able to portray three different characters while putting certain nuances to each of them
The three characters are really different from one another, and you could tell that based on their individual demeanors, personalities, and body languages, which Piolo fantastically depicted
I really hope he wins an award for this, because not many actors could pull this off
And JC Santos… man, he really deserves his Best Supporting Actor award
Even though I was able to predict it easily, I had goosebumps when his character, Lucas, turned out to be the killer in the present day
JC pulled off the Jekyll and Hyde persona so well
He should do this type of role more often
Furthermore, the film did well when it comes to building suspense
Although it is not as scary as typical horror films, the jump scares were still frightening
Additionally, the score and sound effects were spectacular — they fitted every scene perfectly and greatly intensified the eerie atmosphere of the film
And the pacing was surprisingly good
In contrast to most long films, I wasn’t bothered with the runtime of this one
Most scenes were paced appropriately
Overall, disregarding my criticisms, I enjoyed watching this film
It had a lot of wasted potential, but it still gave me a nice cinematic experience

Staying awake was a struggle
Its astounding cinematography cannot salvage this film from the utter ludicrousness of the story
Its premise was interesting
After all, it was supposed to depict the Philippines' first serial killer, Fr
Juan Severino Mallari, a talented calligrapher-turned-murderer priest in Pampanga
Yet, it tried to outsmart its audience by hyping up a confused intergenerational Mallari curse

What came out was a mess littered with pathetically otiose jumpscares, lazy narrations, historical inaccuracies, overstretched fictionalization, and the implausibility of astral projection and time travel
To make matters worse, there were hints of transphobia, racism, and glorification of extrajudicial killings flying all over this film
JC Santos and his deranged act as a killer stood out in this film
And don't fret; that "twist" was given away in the first 15 minutes
Gloria Diaz was great
Piolo Pascual succeeded in crafting three different personas
All weren't enough to make this good enough

The plot actually went crazy, but the vfx
Mallari is a good thriller film if you are craving some thrills
It gives adequate tension for most scenes, with entertaining plot twists for everyone watching
However, it suffered from bad writing and dumb choices
There was an attempt for a relatability in Father Mac's character, but it was too much it feels shoved into the film
Wonder if they paid license from Sueisha and Pierrot for that character that is just used for comedic relief
The marketing of the film is waaay waay off the actual film plot
It tried to incorporate a lot of elements: family, isekai, love, occult, Philippine folklore, and common horror tropes but executed quite badly
It was a clickbait/watchbait to say it is a film about Severino Mallari, but more of a fictionalized character of him (adding the Disclaimer about using St
Bartholomew as a plot device didn't help at all)
The music is too much to aid with horror; it helped me anticipate the jumpscares
There is also a missed opportunity in painting the moon red for trying to tie it into blood moon as well, you know, when blood is involved here
But Piolo and JC Santos carried the film
They both provided some wide range of character
They somehow saved the film
I can also see Piolo in Melvil Poupaud
He somehow styles like him and has aged well
In short, Mallari is like me, quite confusing to discern its main purpose because it went off-tangents and digressions

It wasn't bad by any means, but this movie tried waaaay too hard to be scary
Too many cheap jump scares and the sound design ruined some of the moments
Some of the cgi was horrible too and I wish they used practical effects instead
Speaking of effects, the gore in this movie was weird
It's like they're not afraid to be graphic but they're also not showing how graphic the kills are
Then there's the plot
Lots of misplaced exposition and unanswered questions
Unanswered questions are a good thing but the questions we really needed answers to were never answered
Despite all of these, Mallari had a lot of things going for it
Piolo was great, JC was great, I bet Janella would've been great too if she was given more screen time
I respect their decision to add a more complicated twist to the material at hand, but this would've been better if it was a period piece and focused more on what happened back in 1812
Overall, a good watch but could've been better
