Walang Diyos sa gabi
It’s refreshing to see Piolo Pascual do quadruple duty with his role as Father Juan Severino Mallari, Johnrey Mallari, and Jonathan Mallari de Dios
The film weaves three timelines, allowing the past and present to come full circle
Mallari goes beyond the historical account it is based on and adds a sense of supernatural and spiritual element to the mix, which in some parts worked, and some didn't
The story can go into familiar territory, settling with horror elements from the films in the past, and struggling to reach the film's full potential for the genre
However, much can be said about the film's magnificent and terrorizing score, cinematography, and production design
These aspects elevate the film even further, which is enough to make up for the story's shortcomings

One of the most anticipated films of this year's MMFF is about the curious case of Father Severino Mallari, a real-life Filipino priest who is also the country's first-ever documented serial killer
What makes people even more excited is that this is lead actor #PioloPascual 's first horror film to date, after being tried and tested in romance/drama/comedy genres
This is among the final batch of films announced to be a part of the festival shortlist, which now has 2 entries more than its usual 8
In this film, Pascual plays three distinct characters in different time periods: Doctor Jonathan (present time), war documentarian Johnrey (1940s) and the serial killer Fr
Severino (1800s)
Individually, these key characters all face the fears of their respective eras, while their paths converge in one hidden room of the Mallari mansion
It is delightful to watch Pascual step up his game in portraying the triple characters with distinct personalities, perhaps one of the most memorable performances in this festival
However, #JCSantos brings out the real surprise of this film and there's genuine terror in his character's ultimate reveal
If only the CGI effects were polished and convincing enough, then its horrific atmosphere may have been consistent
The film sure took a risk in mixing a lot of elements that could be too much to absorb in one sitting
Honestly, I would've wanted it to focus more on the killer priest and explore his psyche on a deeper level - his internal battles and the impact of his killings
The concept of an astral time travel could be saved on another film, the blood relation of the three leads may already be used to explain their connection
They could've used the time building up the crime-horror-folklore angles rather than explain all the sci-fi
Still, Mallari is a good attempt at elevating our taste in cinema
May this inspire more filmmakers to experiment in the horror genre

”How far will you go for love
I believe this is the theme of the movie
Father Mallari is a real figure in Philippines history, the first documented serial killer in the country
The movie tells his story from the angle of love and madness
After some researches, I found that the real Father Mallari might have acted with love or he had mental issues

This movie is a fiction based on the real story of Father Mallari; it has a very mysterious background and I like the darkness it presented and how the story didn’t end with political correctness; however, the ending couldn’t have ended earlier
Nevertheless, there are too many jump scares (with unnecessarily too strong sound effect), which didn’t help pushing the plot forward and made it draggy
The acting range (and muscles) of Piolo are amazing; his has 4-style in the movie, if you watch close enough, there is a small detail for the style of Johnathan
Since Piolo has a mole near his left ear, to further differentiate the style of Johnrey and Johnathan, his mole was removed (likely by CG) when he plays Johnathan
JC Santos is really outstanding, he definitely stole the spotlight
The buildup of atmosphere is great, technical aspects are pretty impressive like visual effect, lighting and scores
However, editing seems to be another issue
For example, the scene where Father Mallari just returned home and almost encountered Johnrey and Johnathan, had repeated 3-time in the movie
Is it really necessary or audiences would be that absent-minded
I’m not sure whether relatively jumpy editing is the storytelling style of Director Cabrido, because his last movie      also has this issue

Mallari is hands down one of the best Filipino films I've ever seen
The cinematography is crazy especially in the smooth transitions, with lighting and lines used
The film showcased into the nuanced relationship between religion, kulam, hierarchy, and also shows on how mental illness was once a taboo topic (till now lol)

the story of the original juan severino from 1812, a 1946 Mallari who documents the post-WWII era through film, and a present-day Mallari doctor desperately searching for a cure for his fiancee's future illness
Piolo Pascual played all three Mallaris (fucking goated)
A must watch
Dont forget to bring lotion and tissues

The storyline cleverly deceives you into believing that its plot is predictable, allowing you to anticipate scenes and revelations
However, the meticulous crafting of every detail ensures that, despite the apparent predictability, the execution remains so well-done that you'll still find yourself shocked and frightened
The film achieves this without unnecessarily complicating the narrative, maintaining its effectiveness in delivering surprises and scares
"Mallari" masterfully employs a multi-sensory approach, seamlessly blending visuals and sound to provoke a powerful emotional response from the audience

The effectiveness of the musical scoring becomes evident as it skillfully crafts a suspenseful and frightening atmosphere, enhancing the impact of jump scares and intensifying the overall horror experience
The cast delivered compelling portrayals of their characters, infusing depth and authenticity that kept the audience engaged

Despite the anticipation of impending jump scares, their performances were so effective that even when expected, the audience found themselves screaming in response to the well-executed moments of shock
Contrary to the typical ending associated with this theme, where the protagonist usually finds redemption or breaks free from the negative thread, "Mallari" takes a different approach
The film allows the protagonist to embrace the path of becoming the villain, seemingly without learning from the events of the story, succumbing to darkness

This unexpected twist left a lasting impression, showcasing an innovative narrative where the conventional expectations are skillfully subverted, making the storytelling more impressive in its well-outlined and unconventional trajectory
Hats off to the Mallari Team for creating an outstanding film that truly deserves international recognition
Kudos to everyone involved

A familiar yet refreshing take on Filipino horror
Mallari served as the frontrunner for last year’s MMFF months before the festival
Trailers were good and promotions were good as well, but what surprised me is the difference between the final film and these promotional materials
I was expecting Mallari to be Psychological Thriller or a slasher film but it was meddled with paranormal and time travel
You can already pinpoint who the killer is in the first 30 minutes of the film, which is a bummer
JC Santos gave a splendid performance but his character and the twist of the story could be done better
Magulo yung first act, it felt like marami silang gustong ilagay sa marrative
Lines were cringy and walang tao sa totoong buhay na ganon mag salita
The film also had unnecessary jumpscares na walang purpose sa story, very Filipino horror movie core
The second and the last act is where the story started to take ita shape and form
I was glued down to my seats with what I was watching
Magulo ang simula pero natahi nila nang maayos ang lahat ng elemento sa dulo which is what made me like this film despite its issues
Piolo Pascual showed how great he was in his craft
Sa pelikulang ito makikita mo kung bakit sought after si Piolo
Janella Salvador was also great in this movie, she can be the queen of filipino horror movies
Sound design and the set designs were my favorite, dito mo makikitang pinaghandaan at may malaking budget ang palabas na ito
Mallari has some of the elements of a bad and cringey horror movies but it also has refreshing takes on a newer form of horror and storytelling that uses a lore to expound on a subject matter

Perhaps the most surprising aspect of Mallari is how the director Derick Cabrido managed to weave together a staggering amount of narrative threads and somehow still ended up with a cohesive story

Although the same thing cannot be said about its many thematic layers that often felt convoluted and reactionary, there is something to be admired (or at least respected) with how textually rich Cabrido aims his film to be

Albeit inferred only through the choice of time periods (1818/1948/2018), Mallari succeeds in tracing a historical and cultural perspective on the Duterte drug war–that of a messianic figure (Duterte/Fr

Mallari) assuming the role of both judge and executioner of perceived "plagues" of society (the sinful/addicts)–and clearly demonstrates why this is problematic and is ultimately an act of self-preservation
The film takes a firm stance against mass murder, especially when it is enacted by the elites, and in the current Filipino socio-political climate this sentiment is well-appreciated
However, Mallari's portrayal of folk religion/mythology vis-a-vis Christianity is rather questionable

On one hand the film explores its anti-colonial capacity, that its integration into a Western notion of Christianity did not necessarily result into assimilation; indeed, through sinister shots littered with religious figurines (rooted in pagan worship) and the psychological corruption of Fr

Mallari's morals, the film shows that folk traditions' effects and influences have stood the test of time and could even be argued as the primary feature through which Filipinos practice modern Christianity

On the other hand, however, Mallari is still unable to resist the hegemonic assumptions that these folk practices are inherently evil; they may be anti-colonial but they're just as bad, maybe even worse
They function mainly to bolster the film's hypothesis—that evil is the primary component of the world and that everything else exist only in relation to it

This argument is most explicitly shown through the construction of Casa Mallari as a liminal space, where different temporal (past, present, future) and existential (living and non-living) realities converge

This is also the reason why the scares, although seemingly imitating the effect of sudden shock, are deliberately designed to evoke diminishing affective returns; fear is not an anomaly in the film's diegesis but is rather the norm, further supporting the essentialist view of the world and humanity as evil
And although this position works within the confines of the horror genre in which Mallari operates, I remain not fully sold on such bleak and defeatist attitude
I'd rather believe that there exist other "manlalakbays" (time travelers) with the capacity to intervene and put an end to this cycle of violence

Piolo Pascual has proven why he is still at the top of his game
He has departed from the romantic heartthrob roles and has taken on more challenging and diverse characters than we usually see him in
In "Mallari," he portrays three related characters across different generations
I enjoyed the diversity in each character and how they all have different fates, showcasing various kinds of love
As Severino, the murderous priest with a malicious intent to kill the bad seed in his community and free his mother from a curse, Piolo is very convincing as a serial killer
The transition scene in the church, where he was being convinced by the Patron Saint Bartholomew, was just a chef’s kiss
As Johnrey, Piolo transitions into a man willing to do everything to rid himself of the curse
And as Jonathan, who was willing to do everything to save a loved one, Piolo was so good that you might want to express frustration for all the stupidity and recklessness he portrayed
The ending scene, where Piolo is facing the audience as if telling them that he will be hunting them for the night, is just brilliant
This is a one-of-a-kind Filipino horror movie
Surprisingly good
It keeps you on the edge during the first act but kinda fell down during the second
Third act was predictable but that twist in the end is just so good

Instead of opting for a straightforward depiction of the infamous case of Philippines’ first documented serial killer, Mallari chooses a wild, albeit frustratingly complex, yet enjoyably ambitious approach that may or may not impress you

Premiered at the 2023 Metro Manila Film Festival, this one is definitely a commendable and inspired take on the real-life priest/murderer from the Philippines that combined multiple horror subgenres along with Filipino folklore/mythology and serial killer elements
Some scares did get repetitive and some CGI "money-shot" reveals along with a few blood effects here and there were a bit clunky that kind of took me out of it

It was also not entirely unpredictable considering one of the movie's accolades in the acting category, but the multiple twists along with a few genuinely creepy moments and fine performances surely elevated the movie overall
Certainly worth the watch especially for genre fans

Directed by Roderick Cabrido, this thriller connects the lives of Mallari family members over 30 years, from the 1940s to the present day
The film starts with peaceful scenes in the Philippines, but it gets spooky as strange things start happening

Though there was a tendency to use the cheapest of jump scares, I’d have to say that this was otherwise a fairly effective horror that was pretty decent at atmosphere building
It did drag a bit long at times and there was some confusion with it constantly switching time periods, but I can’t say it was a bad time
Piolo Pascual is a solidly charismatic lead
It was a pretty solid effort even if I wasn’t totally happy with its execution
I can definitely respect the film
This film fumbles its creepy Filipino folklore concept
The concept had potential – a creepy urban legend stemming from a small provincial town, it was an interesting background
The film tries to be complex, weaving multiple narratives and timelines together, delving into astral projects and whatnot
However, this complexity ends up muddying the story instead of enriching it
It feels like the writer bit off more than they could chew, lacking the clear vision needed to pull off a compelling horror or thriller
The tension and suspense, crucial ingredients for any horror film, are noticeably absent
The overall storytelling, from pacing to camerawork, shot selections and editing choices fail to build any real sense of unease, suspense or anticipation; falling short of the genre's demands
With a tighter focus, a clearer narrative structure, and a director with a stronger grasp of the genre, "Mallari" could have been a genuinely scary and unsettling experience
As it stands, it's a forgettable mess

This was a really good film
It shows three perspectives of three different characters played by Piolo Pascual
The nice visual effects were really nice, and I was not expecting the quality to be THAT good
Byfar the BEST Filipino film I’ve seen
It boasts a captivating plot intricately linked to Philippine history and urban legend
The commendable acting skills of all characters significantly contribute to the film’s appeal
The pacing strikes a perfect balance—neither too fast nor too slow, preventing viewers from experiencing boredom, or confusion
Regrettably, the downside lies in the inclusion of unnecessary jump scares, creating an abrupt disruption in the flow of the film
This drawback proves to be a significant dent in the overall quality of an otherwise promising story
Despite this setback, it’s important to note that “Mallari” still stands as a commendable horror film, especially when compared to the usual offerings in the Philippine horror genre
Its compelling plot, historical ties, and the commendable performances of the cast elevate it above many counterparts, making it a worthwhile watch for enthusiasts of the genre
OVERALL 10/10 MAS NINDOT IF SA SINEHAN GYUD LANTAWON THE FOLKLORES, MUSIC, CINEMATOGRAPHY, ACTING, PLOT, EVERTHING WAS ON POINT A MUST WATCH MOVIE

โอ้โหนี่ฉันถ่อมาถึงไอคอนสยามเพื่อดูหนังแบบนี้อ่ะนะ  บาปกว่านั้นคือเพื่อนเกาะไหล่มาดูด้วย ไอเราใช้เอ็มพาสก็เสียดายแค่ค่ารถกับเวลา แต่เพื่อนก็คือเสียค่าตั๋วฉ่ำๆ 180…อ่ะพูดกันตามตรงวัตถุดิบมันก็มีศักยภาพพอจะเป็นหนังสนุกอยู่ ชนบท เรื่องดำมืดในตระกูล นักท่องกาลเวลา ผีเอเชียใต้ชายคาโบถส์คริสต์ การถูกกดทับของชนชั้นล่างที่ถูกปลดปล่อยมาในรูปปีศาจ แต่คือล้มเหลวในการปรุงให้สนุกมากๆ… เทคนิคภาพเกรดบีแบบหนังเด็กมัธยมเมื่อ 10 ปีก่อน ความเล่าเป็นก้อนๆพอถึงจุดพีคก็ตัดฉับไปเล่าก้อนใหม่โดยที่จุดพีคของแต่ละก้อนก็อ้อมแอ้มๆ ถ่ายแบบหลบๆกล้าๆกลัวๆ ความไม่เมคเซนส์ของตัวละคร เหนืออื่นใดคือยืดเยื้อมากๆทำทำไมตั้ง 2 ชั่วโมง 9 นาที จะเล่าหลายเส้นเรื่องแต่จุดที่มันตัดกันก็คือฉายซ้ำไปซ้ำมา ทีเดียวก็รู้เรื่องแล้วคุณพี่

Movie: มัลลารี ตำนานเชือด โลกสะท้าน | Mallariคะเเนนจากเรา : 7 /10คะเเนนจาก Rotten Tometoes  : -- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Review Session  - รีวิว Mallari แรงบันดาลใจจากเรื่องจริง
สู่ภาพยนตร์สยองของฟิลิปปินส์ ที่ได้รับเลือกเข้าฉายในเมโทรมะนิลาฟิล์มเฟสติวัล ครั้งที่ 49 Mallari - ตำนานเชือดโลกสะท้าน ที่ครั้งนี้ทาง Warner Bros

Thailand คว้าตัวนักแสดงหนุ่มอารมณ์ดีอย่าง คุณหยวน กวินรัฏฐ์ ยศอมรสุนทร มาให้เสียงเป็นทั้งหมด 3 ตัวด้วยกันได้แก่ บาทหลวงมัลลารี , นักทำสาคดี จอห์นเรย์ มัลลารี และ คุณหมอ โจนาธาน มัลลารี เป็นหนังที่สยองขวัญที่ระทึกมากๆเลยครับพล็อตเรื่องมีความโดดเด่นมากๆ และตัวแอดนั้นชื่นชอบมากคือการหยิบเอาคนสามไทม์ไลน์มาเชื่อมโยงกัน แต่เรื่องราวนั้นกับเชื่อมกันได้อย่างลงตัว มีแค่บางฉากเท่านั้นที่ตัดสลับแบบฉึบฉับไปบ้าง ตรงนี้อาจทำผู้ชมนั้น งง ง่วยได้ แต่โดยรวมแล้วก็พอจะเข้าใจง่ายอยู่ครับ สำหรับเารเดินเรื่องของหนังเรื่องนี้ แต่ที่เด่นๆเลยก็ขอยกให้ความระทึกขวัญเนี้ยล่ะครับที่ให้อารมณ์เหใอนเราได้ชมหนังผีต่างจังหวัดเลยล่ะครับ ซึ่งฉากระทึกๆนั้นตัวหนังมีเยอะมากๆ แถมทำคนดูขนลุกขนพองกันได้แน่นอนครับ ส่วนฉากที่คิดว่าน่ากลัวนั้นขอยกให้ฉากในบ้านเนี้ยล่ะครับ รับประกันเลยว่าสยองอย่างแน่นอน และตัวหนังยังได้ดัดแปลงมาจากเรื่องจริงอีกมันเลยค่อนข้างที่จะน่าสนใจมากเลยล่ะครับนอกจากความสยองของหนังแล้วตัวหนังยังมีเรื่องราวของทูตผีปีศาจอีกด้วยครับ แต่ตัวแอดนั้นไม่รู้จริงๆว่ามันคือตัวอะไร หรือมันอาจจะเป็นผีพื้นบ้านของฟิลิปปินส์รึเปล่า แต่ก็ทำออกมาได้อย่างน่ากลัวและหลอนมากๆเลยล่ะครับ และในช่วงท้ายตัวหนังยังมีตอนจบที่หักมุมแบบสุดๆอีกด้วยครับส่วนด้านของนักแสดงนั้นก็ทำออกมาได้ดีครับ ดูมีมิติ และน่าติดตามพอสมควรเลยล่ะ และใครที่อยากรู้สัมผัสประสบการณ์ความสยองที่ดัดแปลงมาจากเรื่องจริงฆาตกรต่อเนื่องคนแรกในประวัติศาสตร์ของฟิลิปปินส์ก็ไม่ควรพลาดครับกับ Mallari มัลลารี ตำนานเชือดโลกสะท้านฉายเเล้ววันนี้ในโรงภาพยนต์ทั่วประเทศ

Father Severino: Panganay na mama's boy forever Johnrey: The rationale middle childJonathan: The super spoiled na bunsong sabog ang priorities at decision-making sa buhayI honestly thought it was just a historical fiction drama with a slight side of horror and thriller, but boy I was surprised

Overall, I really liked the technicality of this film [except that manananggal scene that came from nowhere]
The scoring gave justice to how the film should feel like
I went into "Mallari" with a mixture of excitement and skepticism because of how well-received it was by Filipino viewers on social media
Regretfully, the film's execution left me feeling disappointed, and my expectations were not fulfilled
To bring the story to its best, the screenplay in particular needs to be significantly revised
On the one hand, the film's artistic vision is praiseworthy
It is creative and promising that the authors chose to examine several incarnations of the Mallari family in diverse eras
But the execution is inadequate
It's challenging to fully immerse yourself in the characters and their struggles because of the story's rambling dialogue and pacing
Despite being a crucial part of the movie, the big reveal feels hurried and doesn't have the emotional impact it needs
The final choice made by the protagonist, which is supposed to be a pivotal moment in the narrative, is disappointing and has no lasting effect
Additionally, there is no tension or surprise because the criminal killer's identity is revealed right away
Furthermore, the movie's depiction of Mallari's deeds and killings is a little sanitized, which lessens the story's overall impact
The final product does not justify the audience's reaction to the story, nor does it fully realize its complexity
It was a failure all around
Although it had promise, the narrative required a lot of work and changes
The morality of Fr
could have been the subject of the film
Mallari and how his actions' effects were still troublesome
The topic of murder and why it shouldn't be accepted or exalted could have been covered
Props to JC Santos tho

I read an article about the real Father Mallari and why, just why, was his story portrayed in this way
I am not going to talk into detail na about the structure or the scenes of the film basta 'yung feelings ko rollercoaster
Puntahan natin yung mahalaga
The film was supposed to be historic and cultural
No matter what kind of creative tweaks ang niluto nila, hindi ba't pangalan ni Juan Severino Mallari ang ginagamit natin dito
Where was his story
Sa pagkakaunawa ko, tila napunta ang spotlight kay John Rey at Jonathan kung sinuman sila
At tangina pa ni Jonathan
Hindi ito ang kwento ni Father Juan Severino Mallari
Ano kayang sasabihin ni Mallari kung bumangon siya sa hukay niya ngayon

His story is rich with moral dilemmas and gray areas and very significant and relevant topics such as psychological disorders that could have been interpreted and revealed to us in a way na may twist pa rin siguro
without adding those unnecessary fictional elements
This could have been the chance to talk more about the Church and our individual beliefs and how it clashes with each other but they didn't
In fact, bakit hindi na lang nila ginawang drama
Hindi na lang nila ginawang isang pelikula na sa mga susunod na taon ay magiging isang klasiko
Isang mahalagang reperensya
Bakit thriller
Bakit Haunted Mansion style
For the last 20 years most of the Filipino films that have been released are all short-lived
Konting-konti lang ang nagsusurive ng maraming taon at pinapanood at tinatangkilik pa rin hanggang ngayon
This could have been the chance for God's sakes
And, no, we do not need millions of budget to make masterpieces, no
God, wala na sumigi na ako
Hinding hindi maikakaila na lagong-lago ang imahinasyon ng mga taong nasa likod ng pelikulang ito
I liked or maybe loved the creativity that was poured unto to the making of this film
I needed some hope na mayroon pa ring mga sining na pinaghihirapan at hindi pineperahan
And, Mallari maybe gave me that hope, gaano man kaliit
Alam ko na hindi pa rin ito yung ginustong nilang maging katapusan ng pelikula
They were just so limited, perhaps, by factors such as censorship, pressure from corporations from investors
O, kaya, iniisip na lang lagi ng mga filmmakers natin na ang mga manonood ay yung mga casual moviegoers lang, ganon ganon
Ayaw kong maging masyadong harsh sa kanila dahil siguro nahihirapan din sila
Pero, ganito na lang ba palagi
Gustong kong may magbago
Gusto kong may maramdaman ulit akong tindig-balihibo hindi yung pilit na gulat

Mallari (2023) Review:Mallari is a 2023 Philippine horror-drama movie directed by Roderick Cabrido
The screenplay was written by Enrico Santos
It’s produced by Allan V
Aldea, Ronalyn Bana-ag, John Bryan Diamante, Roxan Mendoza, Carl Yvan Dornila, and Gio Medina
The film’s production companies here are Mentorque Productions and Clever Minds Inc
It’s distributed by Warner Bros
Pictures and Star Cinema
It stars Piolo Pascual, Janella Salvador, JC Santos, Elisse Joson Vangie Labalan, Bart Guingona, Ge Villamil, Raffy Tejada, and Gloria Diaz
“The movie is inspired by true events
The story is set in three generations and follows the Mallari family: Juan Severino, John Rey, and Jonathan (all of whom are portrayed by Piolo Pascual)
Juan Severino was a Catholic priest and serial killer during the Spanish colonial era in the Philippines in the 19th century
John Rey is a photo journalist and also the grandnephew of Juan Severino during post-World War II
Johnathan is his great-grandnephew and also a doctor in the modern world
Their stories interlink with one another
”I was honestly looking forward to this film
Ever since I’ve read about its premise, it immediately caught my attention
The trailer was solid
It has a pretty interesting premise
The history that aspects of its story have taken inspiration from catches my attention
If executed properly, this would be a really solid movie
I was eagerly waiting for its release on Netflix, and after finally watching it, I have to say that I was rather disappointed with it
I really wanted to like this film, but there are a lot of things here that are pretty dull
Mallari (2023) is a mixed bag
It’s decently directed, and it also has a solid cast
Visually, it looks great, and the music was excellent
There is some creepy atmosphere here, and again, the premise was interesting
Unfortunately, the film leaves a lot to be desired, especially with its script
It has a very messy, bland, and uninteresting story
The characters are wooden, and a lot of the dialogue was cringeworthy
The pacing is inconsistent, and the scares are very cheap
This film was mediocre
Here are my thoughts on the movie:Positives:- It’s a decently directed film
Roderick Cabrido did a fairly serviceable job with the film’s overall direction
There are definitely some moments here where I can see what they’re going for
As for the cast, I thought they were pretty solid
A lot of the performances here are good
Their chemistry with each other was also fairly decent here
Piolo Pascual’s performance certainly shines throughout the entire duration of the film
He’s performance was good
- Visually, the film actually looks pretty good
There are plenty of shots here that looks excellent, especially the final shot
Some of the camera work that they’ve done here is also pretty good
Aside from its overall cinematography, the film also has a solid atmosphere
There were some moments where I find this aspect to be incredibly effective
The music composed by Von de Guzman is excellent
It fits the tone of the film, and at times, it was effective
- As for its premise, this aspect was the reason I wanted to watch it
The film has a very intriguing premise, and there are moments where I can see the potential
Unfortunately, the execution could’ve been better (more on that later on)
Aside from that, there are a couple of decent moments here and there
There are a couple of creepy moments, especially with the atmosphere
Its production is a mixed bag
At times, this aspect here was fairly decent
Negatives:- As for my issues, despite a pretty interesting premise, the execution certainly leaves a lot to be desired, especially with the script, which was rather lackluster
There are some moments here where I can see the potential that it has, but it often devolves into a generic and messy story
The structure here was all over the place
It doesn’t really help that it was also underdeveloped
It’s really disappointing how underbaked the premise of this movie is
- Not only is the story very lackluster, but the same thing can also be said about the characters themselves
Sure, the performances from the cast members may be solid, the characters that they are portraying, on the other hand, just fall flat to me
I didn’t really care about or find any of them to be all that interesting
The dialogue is also pretty terrible at times
It tries to be modern with its dialogue here, but it usually ends up being really cringeworthy
- Aside from that, the editing here is also pretty choppy
Not only from the overall structure of its narrative but also within its jump scares
Speaking of its jump scares, they aren’t good
Sure, the film can be creepy at times, but it’s not all that scary
The jump scares that it does here often end up being predictable and clichéd
It did this weird edit that was really sloppy
It doesn’t help that the movie also bombards you with unnecessary sound effects
- As for its visual effects, they aren’t good either; they’re actually quite awful
Some of the special effects that it does in here look pretty cheap and noticeable
It could’ve been a lot better
Pacing-wise, this aspect is very inconsistent
There are a couple of moments where the movie is a bit of a drag to get through, and other times, it feels incredibly rushed
It just felt messy
Some scenes here are also pretty lackluster, which affects the pacing even more
Final Thoughts:Overall, Mallari (2023) is such a mixed bag for me
There are aspects here that I really liked, and some that don’t really work whatsoever
It’s a decently directed film by Roderick Cabrido
The premise itself is pretty interesting, and there are a couple of moments here where you can definitely see the potential
As for the cast themselves, they’re pretty good
A lot of the performances are great
There’s also some fairly decent chemistry between the cast members in here
Piolo Pascual shines throughout the movie’s entire runtime
Visually, I think the film actually looks pretty good
There are a couple of terrific shots here and there
The cinematography also does a good job of giving the film a bit of a creepy atmosphere
Aside from that, the music that was composed by Von de Guzman is excellent
This also helps with the film’s atmosphere
The overall production here can be a little bit of a mixed bag, but there are some moments where it was quite decent, in my opinion
Aside from that, there are also a couple of pretty decent moments here and there
Unfortunately, despite an intriguing premise, the execution was just all over the place
The script is pretty lackluster in a lot of aspects, often making its story feel messy and underdeveloped
This was such a shame because there are some moments here where I can see what they’re going for, but the story just felt really generic at times
Aside from its story, the characters here are also rather bland, making me not really care much for any of them
Some of the lines of dialogue here are also pretty awful
They can be cringeworthy
Aside from that, its editing can be very choppy in some scenes, especially when it comes to its jump scares
Speaking of its jump scares, there’s way too much here, and none of them works
They’re just predictable, and there is also an overabundance of sound effects
The visual effects are atrocious, and the pacing here is very inconsistent
There are instances where the film is a bit of a drag to get through
I really wanted to like this film; I really do
But despite some pretty solid ideas, as a whole, this just leaves a lot to be desired
5/10What are your thoughts

this is the characters' review:if there is anything we know about the mallaris, it's that they're devoted to the people they love

father severino mallari, despite being the marketed center of the story as the first serial killer priest in the philippines, turned out to be a tortured character, who was flawed enough to make mistakes and have turbulent emotions about the people he loved
they gave father severino, a supposed serial killer, a heart, and a facet that made him undeniably human
personally, i like when supposed villains/evil characters show that human quality to themselves
severino, all distraught and maddened yet surrendered by the situation of his mother, still found the strength in his knees to dance his monster-turned-mother
sure, poke fun at him and call him a "mama's boy", but it's not like he had a choice in the matter
especially not when the choices were your own mother or your principles
and how many times have our mothers derailed our principles completely
severino's love was devout
moving onto the second mallari, johnrey: i couldn't say much about him that isn't about his intelligence, martyrdom, and commitment to the future generation
johnrey ended the curse by not choosing the same path severino did
johnrey was selfless, and his love didn't manifest in a way that would put others in harm's way
johnrey's love was kind
and to the third mallari, jonathan
amongst the rest, jonathan chose all the wrong choices
even agnes herself said it would've been better had jonathan let him die
jonathan all throughout the film was misleading, taking on the role of an unreliable narrator, or at least, an ambiguous one
if anything, jonathan's love is unrelenting
and to the special mention, lucas
lucas, oh, he could've been everything
had this been an alarcon-centric film, it would still be as interesting

lucas's motivations which eventually flowed into desperation almost sounded as if he wasn't only faithfully attached to jonathan mallari, but also a servant who loved his faulty master through and through
lucas calling jonathan "amo" was something else

i'm not sure whether i'm viewing everything through the colored lenses of queerness, but lucas's devotion to jonathan had undertones of romanticism and obsession that could only be explained if he were in love with him
and such display would make for good alternate universe writings about this story
rip Father Mallari, you would've loved Nanno

Kidding aside, Mallari had lots of potential as a culturally-nuanced Filipino horror film, but fell short on certain aspects
Fictionalizing the life of Fr
Severino Mallari — reported to be the Philippines' first serial killer — into a film that incorporates elements of folk horror, historical fiction, science fiction, and thriller was promising

It succeeded in drawing upon elements of folk religion and true crime to invite viewers into the life and motives of a creepy and murderous priest, and Piolo Pascual — timeless of an actor he is — nailed the triple roles of Fr
Mallari, Johnrey, and Jonathan quite excellently
The storytelling and production design were quite able to establish the settings in each of the Mallari eras, but the horror elements of the film were left to be desired
The jump scares felt gimmicky and did not serve any real purpose to the storyline other than to imply that Johnrey and Jonathan had psychic abilities

The suspense was present, though I wish Mallari had touched upon the concepts of folk religion and witchcraft a little further to better understand the sociocultural contexts in which the settings of the film revolved in
The motives behind Maria Capac's practice of witchcraft wasn't made clear, apart from maybe the implication that peasant folk like them just wanted to exact revenge on the elite

It would've been nice if the subversiveness of the practice of occultism had been given better emphasis within the contexts of colonial and post-war Philippines, but maybe that's just the sociological analysis-hungry viewer in me wanting more lol

There were also moments when I felt as if the depiction of occultism in the film was a little clichéd ("impoverished househelp uses dark magic against the rich people they serve" felt a little telenovela-esque), but maybe that was intentional to reflect its generally taboo reputation

I did notice, however, similarities in the portrayal of the practice with what was shown in Lorcan Finnegan's Nocebo (2023), where Chai Fonacier played a vengeful mangkukulam disguised as a timid homeopathy-practicing OFW
But all in all, Mallari is a refreshing take on horror, especially for a MMFF release
It's dark, eerie, and adds to the foray of contemporary Filipino media that draws inspiration from real historical events and figures
I'm no horror enthusiast, but I do appreciate it when a Filipino film weaves our history and culture into its storytelling
especially when it includes the parts of our culture that are often left in the dark

The first couple of scenes elicited gasps & ‘wtfs’ from me but I feel like it ultimately became a rather polished version of KMJS’ gabi ng lagim special from the middle towards the end lol
May serial killer, may astral prjection, may mambabarang, cult-ish yung line of servants ng family… by the time na naging manananggal si Gloria Diaz medyo bumitaw na ako ng very light sa plot
I’m a sucker for generational curses though, so I still enjoyed seeing three generations of Mallari men trying to save the one they love the most, kebs na sa eternal damnation, ganon
My favorite scenes were the interactions of Mallari men, and I loved the concept of being able to return to a specific time by carrying a Mallari keepsake with them when they sleep
What else… oh, medyo tumatak yung acting ni Elisse dito — the way she delivered her coconut line was smooth, believable yung implied background ng character niya
The jumpscares were pretty weak, the writing was a little all over the place, but most of the actors were good in the roles given to them
I feel like it could’ve been a shorter film, though
I wish they chose fewer folk / supernatural tales to incorporate in the story
That would’ve made the movie’s plot tighter and maybe, a bit more compelling

Sa direksiyon ni Derick Cabrido at panulat ni Enrico Santos, isa itong pelikulang horror na tungkol sa isang doktor na si Jonathan Mallari De Dios (Piolo Pascual) na bumalik sa bahay ng kanilang angkan upang hanapin ang maaaring lunas sa sakit ng kaniyang fiancee na si Agnes (Janella Salvador)
Habang hinahanap niya ito, matutuklasan niya ang sikreto ng kanilang angkan partikular sa buhay nina John Rey Mallari na isang dokumentarista at Fr
Severino Mallari na isang pari at pinaniniwalaang unang serial killer sa bansa
Mapupuri ko ang pelikula sa effort nito na tahakin ang ibang direksiyon sa halip na magtuon lamang sa sub genre ng horror na slasher o patayan
Sa kasamaang palad, sa sobrang gustong pagsanibin ang halos lahat ng mga elemento rito ng horror, naging magulo na ito
Kahit iyong paggamit ng konsepto ng time travel at astral projection ay magulo para sa akin sapagkat sa pagkakaalam ko, magkaiba ang dalawang ito
Mas nakagulo pa sa pelikula ang pag-eedit nito ng di-linyar na pagsasalaysay dahil sa ilang paulit-ulit na eksena na tingin ko, puwede pang gawing pulido sa isahang pagpapakita lamang
Hindi rin gaanong nabigyan ng linaw ang motibo ng pamilya Alarcon sa pamilya Mallari
Kapuri-puri din ang disenyong pamproduksiyon nito ngunit napag-iwanan naman ang visual effects nito gayong medyo bumubuti naman ito
Napag-iwanan kasi isa sa mga prodyuser nito ay Warner Bros
Philippines tapos ganoon lang ang inabot ng VFX
Ewan ko ba

Bilang karagdagan, ayos din naman ang sinematograpiya at musika at tunog nito ngunit dahil naging paulit-ulit ang paglapat ng musika sa pare-parehong jump scares, ang unang karanasan na nakakagulat ay naging nakaiirita habang tumatagal
Sa tuwing may paparating na halatang jump scare, napapairap na lang ako at minsan, napapabuntunghininga
Sa pagganap naman ni Piolo Pascual, hindi ko nakitaan ng pagkakaiba-iba ang tatlong Mallari
Parang pare-parehong Jonathan lamang ang nakikita ko na nag-iba-iba lamang ng bihis
Marahil, nakaapekto rito ang kulang na karakterisasyon nina John Rey na nalimitahan lamang sa pagiging dokumentarista at Jonathan na nalimitihan lamang sa papel nito sa buhay ni Agnes
Kung mayroon man akong papupurihan kay Pascual, iyon ay ang eksena matapos ang una niyang pagpatay na lumabas ang kaniyang kakayahan bilang aktor sa drama
Bukod pa rito, iyong alter ego ni Fr
Severino Mallari na nakabihis bilang San Bartolome, mahusay

"Directed by Roderick Cabrido, the Filipino horror film Mallari stars Piolo Pascual as the three main characters living in different time periods: Juan Severino Mallari, Johnrey, and Jonathan
The film is centered around the Mallari family from Magalang, Pampanga
In 2023, Jonathan, a doctor, returned to his ancestral property in Magalang to find the cure for his wife’s illness, and that was when the supernatural phenomena began
The film is inspired by the real-life story of Father Juan Severino Mallari of Magalang, Pampanga, infamous for killing 57 people
Mallari adds a supernatural element to the story and takes it up a notch
From astral projection to time travel, the film offers an elaborate explanation to connect the three timelines

Mallari feels like a rollercoaster ride watching it where you are bombarded with too many things going on, too many information that isn’t put to light
It becomes very awry and sleazy as the film drags on, hoping to reach a certain angle that only becomes a disappointment especially for horror fans
There were so much that bothered me from this one especially as a horror and film fan
And it didn’t help knowing that Mallari is based on a real person

The lore of it all, the “astral projection” being a dumb plot device, the time-jumps, the weird cuts that produced so many continuity errors, the visual effects, the many information that didn’t really work…consuming everything from this film is draining
The only merit I would give this film is JC Santos’ performance that always has me in awe
He can play any sort of role perfectly that just suits him
Also the cinematography that had great camera tricks using the Dutch angles and that one scene using mirror between JC Santos & Piolo Pascual’s fight in the end
The point for this film was to follow the true story of Mallari, the Philippines’ first ever recorded serial killer from the 19th century

Except it was all a ploy to lure people in, making its audience expect a biopic of some sort of a serial killer that only became stupid, fictionalizing almost everything there is to Mallari and making the audience see that serial killers can have good intentions

There are a few serial killer films/shows that actually lets its audience look further into the person’s story (or from their perspective), yet also distinguishing the fact that these people are villains and that you have to understand that you are seeing everything from the villain’s eyes
Or in this case, a serial killer
they made a couple of corny choices but the whole of the story was actually really good and worth watching

The movie is based on the true story of the first documented Filipino serial killer, who happened to be a priest
The non-linear narrative, which involves time travel, can be confusing at first, but the film's eerie atmosphere and strong performances keep viewers engaged
Gloria Diaz delivers a chilling performance, and JC Santos is equally impressive
The casting of theater actors in supporting roles elevates the overall quality of the performances
The incorporation of Filipino folk mysticism, including the aswang, adds depth and quality to the film
The camera angles of this film are insane
I also find the intricate and profound usage of the Filipino language blissful to the ears
If there’s an element in this two-hour film that kept me entertained, that’s it
The cast also gave very satisfactory performances

Juan Severino Mallari was a parish priest during the Spanish colonial period
He reportedly murdered 57 people to aid his ailing mother, and he was believed to have a mental disorder
His story wasn't talked about often up to this day

When I first saw the trailer for this last MMFF I was onboard with it
I read ahead about what Fr
Severino Mallari was all about
Biopics are my bread and butter, and with every biopic, or in this case, an adaptation, I anticipate a degree of creative storytelling to make it more feasable for cinema
What was the films take on this
A Generational "curse" in the Mallari family
The real Mallari was allegedly scizhophrenic; so I was hoping theyd explore that, a mental illness angle plaguing the family for generations
Much to my disappointment, the movie veered away from that and laid blame not into the serial killer but to an entirely fictional group of people who "used" this serial killer to kill
Severino (Piolo Pascual) was essentially forced to kill out of love
A theme which kind of fell flat because of how many things the film wanted to juggle
Was it a mystery
Was it a thriller
A supernatural horror
A sci-fi
Yes, sci-fi

Taking away Fr Severino's agency erases or paints the actions of the real Mallari as not his own choice; if it was indeed mental illness it wouldve made more sense but instead it was the malicious work of well meaning witches
Which, in an original story MAY work, but not in this
Its supposed to be BASED on a real story yet it strayed a little too much into fiction
A creative choice that MIGHTVE worked if only they didnt add astral projection and timey wimey shit into it too
OH plus origins of a notorious Philippine mythic creature
There were some creative shots here and there, I particularly liked this one shot when John was walking through a door and a dolly zoom boxed him in the corridor
However the scares were lack luster
It relied heavily jumpscares which became old fast and can be easily expected
While the makeup and visual effects were great, I dont think it utilized it enough to anything other than
** SPOILERS FOR THE ENDING **god I hated ending

Heres DOCTOR John Mallari; granted hes a pediatrician (I think) with a FIANCE whose also a DOCTOR thats dying bc she got stabbed, his first response was NOT to bring her to a nearby hospital for first aid
And despite being on life support clearly conscious and capable of surviving given medical aid, MISTER JOHNATAN STILL DECIDES TO BRING BACK THE BIRD AND TAKE THE CURSE

WHICH IS THE WORST WAY TO GIVE AGENCY BACK TO THE MALLARI FAMILY when the previous 2 mallari's tried retreiving their lost agency by breaking the curse only for millenial Piolo Pascual to take it back
In summary, story is Messy
Acting is subpar, EXCEPT for JC Santos he stole the show
He was amazing and a twist I saw a mile a way but still welcome because of how well he acted
This movie couldve been something but ended being about nothing

Maganda yung kuwento kaso hindi pulido ang writing
'Yung mga linyahan sa umpisa, trying hard masyado para maging relatable sa audience, to the point na nagiging tunog artificial na
'Yung mga eksena ng trans, sana mas pinag-isipan pa
'Yung mga jump scares, hindi epektib maliban sa isa
I think kinulang sa creativity, kasi malaki ang potensyal ng kwento para manakot at manggulat
Kaso masyadong dumepende sa cuts at sound effects
Pero maganda ang concept
Nakakamangha 'yung second half nang nailatag na ang mga sikreto at misteryo
Complex ang kwento, kaya nakakabilib na maayos itong naihayag
Sa second half din mas nag-shine ang performances ng mga bida
JC Santos, deserving ng best supporting actor sa mmff
And Piolo Pascual, perfect casting
May isang scene na tumatak sa akin dahil sa performanceS niya
All in all, 3/5 kasi medyo na-outweigh pa rin ng flaws ng pelikula ang good aspects nito
May magagandang creative choices in terms of filmmaking, pero sana mas napagtuunan din ng pansin ang mga "scares
" Goosebumps din sana pagdating sa ending, kung mas nabigyan pa ng justification ang mga desisyon ng bida
Pero in the end, very authentic ang istorya, with some all-timer performances

I am so happy with how Philippine Cinema is Progressing
Mallari is a great manifestation of that progress
The storyline was great and I loved how they stitched the plot all together in the end
Cinematography is great and the transition was okay, much more than I expected
Piolo P’s acting was spectacular
The way he managed to separate each character that he was playing and he played them all well
JC Santos was also UH-MAZING
Although I believe that his character arc was quite predictable, he still managed to leave me in awe with how he portrayed his villain character well
The injection of The Philippine Lore was also great and I loved it so much
Overall a great experience with my family and friends

putting jest aside, i came to a realization that this nail-biting Filipino film, inspired by true events yet interwoven with fictional elements, fundamentally springs from undying love
each character, driven by their own ambitions, had one thing in common: their actions were motivated by love
among Piolo's three portrayals in "Mallari"—Severino, Johnrey, and Jonathan—it was Johnrey i found as the most courageous character
his initial ambition to investigate the Mallari family's history and his selfless sacrifices, motivated by love, set him apart
meanwhile, Jonathan’s determination to keep Agnes alive demonstrated a different facet of this enduring theme
as for severino, i sympathized with him, recognizing that he never truly desired the tragic events that transpired
yet, he continued to submit himself in vicious killings to save his beloved mother which only reveal that desperate times need desperate actions
